Complexity and Approximation of Fixing Numerical Attributes in Databases Under Integrity Constraintsâ€ â€ thanks: Dedicated to the memory of Alberto Mendelzon. Our research on this topic started with conversations between Loreto Bravo and him. Alberto was always generous with his time, advice and ideas; our community is already missing him very much.

Leopoldo Bertossi â€ƒâ€ƒ Â Â  Loreto Bravo
Carleton University â€ƒâ€ƒ School of Computer Science â€ƒâ€ƒ Ottawa â€ƒâ€ƒ Canada.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â {bertossi â€ƒâ€ƒ lbravo}@scs.carleton.ca
Enrico Franconi â€ƒâ€ƒ Â Â  Andrei Lopatenko
Free University of Bozenâ€“Bolzano Also: University of Manchester, Department of Computer Science, UK. â€ƒâ€ƒ Faculty of Computer Science â€ƒâ€ƒ Italy.
{franconi â€ƒâ€ƒ lopatenko}@inf.unibz.it
Abstract

Consistent query answering is the problem of computing the answers from a database that are consistent with respect to certain integrity constraints that the database as a whole may fail to satisfy. Those answers are characterized as those that are invariant under minimal forms of restoring the consistency of the database. In this context, we study the problem of repairing databases by fixing integer numerical values at the attribute level with respect to denial and aggregation constraints. We introduce a quantitative definition of database fix, and investigate the complexity of several decision and optimization problems, including DFP, i.e. the existence of fixes within a given distance from the original instance, and CQA, i.e. deciding consistency of answers to aggregate conjunctive queries under different semantics. We provide sharp complexity bounds, identify relevant tractable cases; and introduce approximation algorithms for some of those that are intractable. More specifically, we obtain results like undecidability of existence of fixes for aggregation constraints; MAXSNP-hardness of DFP, but a good approximation algorithm for a relevant special case; and intractability but good approximation for CQA for aggregate queries for one database atom denials (plus built-ins).

1 Introduction

Integrity constraints (ICs) are used to impose semantics on a database with the purpose of making the database an accurate model of an application domain. Database management systems or application programs enforce the satisfaction of the ICs by rejecting undesirable updates or executing additional compensating actions. However, there are many situations where we need to interact with databases that are inconsistent in the sense that they do not satisfy certain desirable ICs. In this context, an important problem in database research consists in characterizing and retrieving consistent data from inconsistent databases [5], in particular consistent answers to queries. From the logical point of view, consistently answering a query posed to an inconsistent database amounts to evaluating the truth of a formula against a particular class of first-order structures [3], as opposed to the usual process of truth evaluation in a single structure (the relational database).

Certain database applications, like census, demographic, financial, and experimental data, contain quantitative data, usually associated to nominal or qualitative data, e.g. number of children associated to a household identification code (or address); or measurements associated to a sample identification code. Usually this kind of data contains errors or mistakes with respect to certain semantic constraints. For example, a census form for a particular household may be considered incorrect if the number of children exceeds 20; or if the age of a parent is less than 10. These restrictions can be expressed with denial integrity constraints, that prevent some attributes from taking certain values [11]. Other restrictions may be expressed with aggregation ICs, e.g. the maximum concentration of certain toxin in a sample may not exceed a certain specified amount; or the number of married men and married women must be the same. Inconsistencies in numerical data can be resolved by changing individual attribute values, while keeping values in the keys, e.g. without changing the household code, the number of children is decreased considering the admissible values.

We consider the problem of fixing integer numerical data wrt certain constraints while (a) keeping the values for the attributes in the keys of the relations, and (b) minimizing the quantitative global distance between the original and modified instances. Since the problem may admit several global solutions, each of them involving possibly many individual changes, we are interested in characterizing and computing data and properties that remain invariant under any of these fixing processes. We concentrate on denial and aggregation constraints; and conjunctive queries, with or without aggregation.

Database repairs have been studied in the context of consistent query answering (CQA), i.e. the process of obtaining the answers to a query that are consistent wrt a given set of ICs [3] (c.f. [5] for a survey). There, consistent data is characterized as invariant under all minimal forms of restoring consistency, i.e. as data that is present in all minimally repaired versions of the original instance (the repairs). Thus, an answer to a query is consistent if it can be obtained as a standard answer to the query from every possible repair. In most of the research on CQA, a repair is a new instance that satisfies the given ICs, but differs from the original instance by a minimal set, under set inclusion, of (completely) deleted or inserted tuples. Changing the value of a particular attribute can be modelled as a deletion followed by an insertion, but this may not correspond to a minimal repair. However, in certain applications it may make more sense to correct (update) numerical values only in certain attributes. This requires a new definition of repair that considers: (a) the quantitative nature of individual changes, (b) the association of the numerical values to other key values; and (c) a quantitative distance between database instances.

Example 1

Consider a network traffic database Dğ·Ditalic_D that stores flow measurements of links in a network. This network has two types of links, labelled 00 and 1111, with maximum capacities 1000100010001000 and 1500150015001500, resp.

Traffic Time Link Type Flow
1.1 a 0 1100
1.1 b 1 900
1.3 b 1 850

Database Dğ·Ditalic_D is inconsistent wrt this IC. Under the tuple and set oriented semantics of repairs [3], there is a unique repair, namely deleting tuple ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘(1.1,a,0,{\it Traffic}(1.1,a,0,italic_Traffic ( 1.1 , italic_a , 0 , 1100)1100)1100 ). However, we have two options that may make more sense than deleting the flow measurement, namely updating the violating tuple to ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘(1.1,a,0,{\it Traffic}(1.1,a,0,italic_Traffic ( 1.1 , italic_a , 0 , 1000)1000)1000 ) or to ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘â¢(1.1,a,1,1100)ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘1.1ğ‘11100{\it Traffic}(1.1,a,1,1100)italic_Traffic ( 1.1 , italic_a , 1 , 1100 ); satisfying an implicit requirement that the numbers should not change too much. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Update-based repairs for restoring consistency are studied in [25]; where changing values in attributes in a tuple is made a primitive repair action; and semantic and computational problems around CQA are analyzed from this perspective. However, peculiarities of changing numerical attributes are not considered, and more importantly, the distance between databases instances used in [25, 26] is based on set-theoretic homomorphisms, but not quantitative, as in this paper. In [25] the repaired instances are called fixes, a term that we keep here (instead of repairs), because our basic repair actions are also changes of (numerical) attribute values. In this paper we consider fixable attributes that take integer values and the quadratic, Euclidean distance L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT between database instances. Specific fixes and approximations may be different under other distance functions, e.g. the â€œcity distanceâ€ L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the sum of absolute differences), but the general (in)tractability and approximation results remain. However, moving to the case of real numbers will certainly bring new issues that require different approaches; they are left for ongoing and future research. Actually it would be natural to investigate them in the richer context of constraint databases [18].

The problem of attribute-based correction of census data forms is addressed in [11] using disjunctive logic programs with stable model semantics. Several underlying and implicit assumptions that are necessary for that approach to work are made explicit and used here, extending the semantic framework of [11].

We provide semantic foundations for fixes that are based on changes on numerical attributes in the presence of key dependencies and wrt denial and aggregate ICs, while keeping the numerical distance to the original database to a minimum. This framework introduces new challenging decision and optimization problems, and many algorithmic and complexity theoretic issues. We concentrate in particular on the â€œDatabase Fix Problemâ€ (DFP), of determining the existence of a fix at a distance not bigger than a given bound, in particular considering the problems of construction and verification of such a fix. These problems are highly relevant for large inconsistent databases. For example, solving DFP can help us find the minimum distance from a fix to the original instance; information that can be used to prune impossible branches in the process of materialization of a fix. The CQA problem of deciding the consistency of query answers is studied wrt decidability, complexity, and approximation under several alternative semantics.

We prove that DFP and CQA become undecidable in the presence of aggregation constraints. However, DFP is NP-complete for linear denials, which are enough to capture census like applications. CQA belongs to Î 2PsubscriptsuperscriptÎ ğ‘ƒ2\Pi^{P}_{2}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and becomes Î”2PsubscriptsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ2\Delta^{P}_{2}roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-hard, but for a relevant class of denials we get tractability of CQA to non aggregate queries, which is again lost with aggregate queries. Wrt approximation, we prove that DFP is ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard in general, and for a relevant subclass of denials we provide an approximation within a constant factor that depends on the number of atoms in them. All the algorithmic and complexity results, unless otherwise stated, refer to data complexity [2], i.e. to the size of the database that here includes a binary representation for numbers. For complexity theoretic definitions and classical results we refer to [21].

This paper is structured as follows. Section 2 introduces basic definitions. Sections 3 presents the notion of database fix, several notions of consistent answer to a query; and some relevant decision problems. Section 4 investigates their complexity. In Section 5 approximations for the problem of finding the minimum distance to a fix are studied, obtaining negative results for the general case, but good approximation for the class of local denial constraints. Section 6 investigates tractability of CQA for conjunctive queries and denial constraints containing one database atom plus built-ins. Section 7 presents some conclusions and refers to related work. Proofs and other auxiliary, technical results can be found in Appendix 0.A.1.

2 Preliminaries

Consider a relational schema Î£=(ğ’°,â„›,â„¬,ğ’œ)Î£ğ’°â„›â„¬ğ’œ\Sigma=({\cal U},{\cal R},{\cal B},{\cal A})roman_Î£ = ( caligraphic_U , caligraphic_R , caligraphic_B , caligraphic_A ), with domain ğ’°ğ’°{\cal U}caligraphic_U that includes â„¤,â„¤\mathbb{Z},blackboard_Z ,111With simple denial constraints, numbers can be restricted to, e.g. â„•â„•\mathbb{N}blackboard_N or {0,1}01\{0,1\}{ 0 , 1 }. â„›â„›{\cal R}caligraphic_R a set of database predicates, â„¬â„¬{\cal B}caligraphic_B a set of built-in predicates, and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A a set of attributes. A database instance is a finite collection Dğ·Ditalic_D of database tuples, i.e. of ground atoms Pâ¢(cÂ¯)ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ‘P(\bar{c})italic_P ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG ), with Pâˆˆâ„›ğ‘ƒâ„›P\in{\cal R}italic_P âˆˆ caligraphic_R and cÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{c}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG a tuple of constants in ğ’°ğ’°\cal Ucaligraphic_U. Attributes outside â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F are called rigid. â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F need not contain all the numerical attributes, that is we may also have rigid numerical attributes.

We consider aggregation constraints (ACs) [23] and aggregate queries with sum, count, average. Filtering ACs impose conditions on the tuples over which aggregation is applied, e.g. ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘š(A1:A2=3)> 5{\it sum}(A_{1}\!:A_{2}=3)\ >\ 5italic_sum ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 ) > 5 is a sum over A1subscriptğ´1A_{1}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of tuples with A2=3subscriptğ´23A_{2}=3italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3. Multi-attribute ACs allow arithmetical combinations of attributes as arguments for ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘š{\it sum}italic_sum, e.g. sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(A1+A2)>5ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šsubscriptğ´1subscriptğ´25sum(A_{1}+A_{2})>5italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 5 and sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(A1Ã—A2)>100ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šsubscriptğ´1subscriptğ´2100sum(A_{1}\times A_{2})>100italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 100. If an AC has attributes from more than one relation, it is multi-relation, e.g. sâ¢uâ¢mR1â¢(A1)=sâ¢uâ¢mR2â¢(A1)ğ‘ ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘…1subscriptğ´1ğ‘ ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘…2subscriptğ´1sum_{R_{1}}(A_{1})=sum_{R_{2}}(A_{1})italic_s italic_u italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_s italic_u italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), otherwise it is single-relation.

An aggregate conjunctive query has the form q(x1,â€¦xm;ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”(z))â†B(x1,q(x_{1},\ldots x_{m};~{}{\it agg}(z))\leftarrow B(x_{1},italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_agg ( italic_z ) ) â† italic_B ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦,â€¦\ldots,â€¦ , xm,subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘šx_{m},italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , z,y1,â€¦,ğ‘§subscriptğ‘¦1â€¦z,y_{1},\ldots,italic_z , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , yn)y_{n})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”{\it agg}italic_agg is an aggregation function and its non-aggregate matrix (NAM) given by qâ€²(x1,â€¦xm)â†B(x1,â€¦,xm,q^{\prime}(x_{1},\ldots x_{m})\leftarrow B(x_{1},\ldots,x_{m},italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â† italic_B ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , zğ‘§zitalic_z, y1,â€¦,subscriptğ‘¦1â€¦y_{1},\ldots,italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , yn)y_{n})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a usual first-order (FO) conjunctive query with built-in atoms, such that the aggregation attribute zğ‘§zitalic_z does not appear among the xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here we use the set semantics. An aggregate conjunctive query is cyclic (acyclic) if its NAM is cyclic (acyclic) [2].

Example 3

qâ¢(x,y,sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z))â†Râ¢(x,y),Qâ¢(y,z,w),â†ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤q(x,y,sum(z))\leftarrow R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),italic_q ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) â† italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , wâ‰ 3ğ‘¤3w\neq 3italic_w â‰  3 is an aggregate conjunctive query, with aggregation attribute zğ‘§zitalic_z. Each answer (x,y)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y ) to its NAM, i.e. to qâ¢(x,y)â†Râ¢(x,y),Qâ¢(y,z,w),wâ‰ 3formulae-sequenceâ†ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤ğ‘¤3q(x,y)\leftarrow R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),w\neq 3italic_q ( italic_x , italic_y ) â† italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , italic_w â‰  3, is expanded to (x,y,sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z))ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§(x,y,sum(z))( italic_x , italic_y , italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) as an answer to the aggregate query. Â sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z)ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§sum(z)italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) is the sum of all the values for zğ‘§zitalic_z having a wğ‘¤witalic_w, such that (x,y,z,w)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤(x,y,z,w)( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) makes Râ¢(x,y),Qâ¢(y,z,w),wâ‰ 3ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤ğ‘¤3R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),w\neq 3italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , italic_w â‰  3 true. In the database instance D={R(1,2),D=\{R(1,2),italic_D = { italic_R ( 1 , 2 ) , Râ¢(2,3),ğ‘…23R(2,3),italic_R ( 2 , 3 ) , Qâ¢(2,5,9),Qâ¢(2,6,7),ğ‘„259ğ‘„267Q(2,5,9),Q(2,6,7),italic_Q ( 2 , 5 , 9 ) , italic_Q ( 2 , 6 , 7 ) , Qâ¢(3,1,1),Qâ¢(3,1,5),ğ‘„311ğ‘„315Q(3,1,1),Q(3,1,5),italic_Q ( 3 , 1 , 1 ) , italic_Q ( 3 , 1 , 5 ) , Q(3,8,3)}Q(3,8,3)\}italic_Q ( 3 , 8 , 3 ) } the answer set for the aggregate query is {(1,2,5+6),(2,3,1+1)}12562311\{(1,2,5+6),(2,3,1+1)\}{ ( 1 , 2 , 5 + 6 ) , ( 2 , 3 , 1 + 1 ) }. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

An aggregate comparison query is a sentence of the form qâ¢(ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”â¢(z)),ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”â¢(z)â¢Î¸â¢kğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”ğ‘§ğœƒğ‘˜q({\it agg}(z)),{\it agg}(z)\theta kitalic_q ( italic_agg ( italic_z ) ) , italic_agg ( italic_z ) italic_Î¸ italic_k, where qâ¢(ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”â¢(z))ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘”ğ‘§q({\it agg(z)})italic_q ( italic_agg ( italic_z ) ) is the head of a scalar aggregate conjunctive query (with no free variables), Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ is a comparison operator, and kğ‘˜kitalic_k is an integer number. For example, the following is an aggregate comparison query asking whether the aggregated value obtained via qâ¢(sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z))ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§q(sum(z))italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) is bigger than 5: Q:qâ¢(sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z)),sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z)>5:ğ‘„ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§5Q\!:q(sum(z)),sum(z)>5italic_Q : italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) , italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) > 5, with qâ¢(sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z))â†Râ¢(x,y),Qâ¢(y,z,w),wâ‰ 3formulae-sequenceâ†ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘„ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¤ğ‘¤3q(sum(z))\leftarrow R(x,y),Q(y,z,w),w\neq 3italic_q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) â† italic_R ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_Q ( italic_y , italic_z , italic_w ) , italic_w â‰  3.

3 Least Squares Fixes

When we update numerical values to restore consistency, it is desirable to make the smallest overall variation of the original values, while considering the relative relevance or specific scale of each of the fixable attributes. Since the original instance and a fix will share the same key values (c.f. Definition 2), we can use them to compute variations in the numerical values. For a tuple kÂ¯Â¯ğ‘˜\bar{k}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG of values for the key KRsubscriptğ¾ğ‘…K_{\!R}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of relation Rğ‘…Ritalic_R in an instance Dğ·Ditalic_D, tÂ¯â¢(kÂ¯,R,D)Â¯ğ‘¡Â¯ğ‘˜ğ‘…ğ·\bar{t}(\bar{k},R,D)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG , italic_R , italic_D ) denotes the unique tuple tÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¡\bar{t}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG in relation Rğ‘…Ritalic_R in instance Dğ·Ditalic_D whose key value is kÂ¯Â¯ğ‘˜\bar{k}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG. To each attribute Aâˆˆâ„±ğ´â„±A\in{\cal F}italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_F a fixed numerical weight Î±Asubscriptğ›¼ğ´\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is assigned.

Definition 1

For instances Dğ·{\it D}italic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²{\it D}^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over schema Î£normal-Î£\Sigmaroman_Î£ with the same set ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™â¢(KR)ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ¾ğ‘…{\it val}(K_{\!R})italic_val ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of tuples of key values for each relation Râˆˆâ„›ğ‘…â„›R\in{\cal R}italic_R âˆˆ caligraphic_R, their square distance is
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Î”Î±Â¯â¢(D,Dâ€²)=âˆ‘kÂ¯âˆˆğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™â¢(KR)Râˆˆâ„›,Aâˆˆâ„±Î±Aâ¢(Ï€Aâ¢(tÂ¯â¢(kÂ¯,R,D))âˆ’Ï€Aâ¢(tÂ¯â¢(kÂ¯,R,Dâ€²)))2,subscriptnormal-Î”normal-Â¯ğ›¼ğ·superscriptğ·normal-â€²subscriptsuperscriptnormal-Â¯ğ‘˜ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ¾ğ‘…formulae-sequenceğ‘…â„›ğ´â„±subscriptğ›¼ğ´superscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ´normal-Â¯ğ‘¡normal-Â¯ğ‘˜ğ‘…ğ·subscriptğœ‹ğ´normal-Â¯ğ‘¡normal-Â¯ğ‘˜ğ‘…superscriptğ·normal-â€²2\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}({\it D},{\it D}^{\prime})=\sum_{\stackrel{{\scriptstyle R\in{\cal R},A\in{\cal F}}}{{\bar{k}\in{\it val}(K_{\!R})}}}\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}(\pi_{\!{}_{A}}(\bar{t}(\bar{k},R,D))-\pi_{\!{}_{A}}(\bar{t}(\bar{k},R,D^{\prime})))^{2},roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG âˆˆ italic_val ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_R âˆˆ caligraphic_R , italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_F end_ARG end_RELOP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG , italic_R , italic_D ) ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_k end_ARG , italic_R , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
where Ï€Asubscriptğœ‹ğ´\pi_{\!{}_{A}}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the projection on attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A and Î±Â¯=(Î±A)Aâˆˆâ„±normal-Â¯ğ›¼subscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ´ğ´â„±\bar{\alpha}=(\alpha_{\!{}_{A}})_{A\in{\cal F}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG = ( italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Definition 2

For an instance Dğ·Ditalic_D, a set of fixable attributes â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F, a set of key dependencies ğ’¦ğ’¦{\cal K}caligraphic_K, such that DâŠ§ğ’¦modelsğ·ğ’¦D\models{\cal K}italic_D âŠ§ caligraphic_K, and a set of flexible ICs IC: Â A fix for Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC is an instance Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that: (a) Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the same schema and domain as Dğ·Ditalic_D; (b) Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the same values as Dğ·Ditalic_D in the attributes in ğ’œâˆ–â„±ğ’œâ„±{\mathcal{A}}\smallsetminus{\cal F}caligraphic_A âˆ– caligraphic_F; (c) Dâ€²âŠ§ğ’¦modelssuperscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ’¦D^{\prime}\models{\cal K}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§ caligraphic_K; and (d) Dâ€²âŠ§ğ¼ğ¶modelssuperscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ¼ğ¶D^{\prime}\models{\textit{IC}}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§ IC.Â  A least squares fix (LS-fix) for Dğ·Ditalic_D is a fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes the square distance Î”Î±Â¯â¢(D,Dâ€²)subscriptnormal-Î”normal-Â¯ğ›¼ğ·superscriptğ·normal-â€²\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}(D,D^{\prime})roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) over all the instances that satisfy (a) - (d). â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

In general we are interested in LS-fixes, but (non-necessarily minimal) fixes will be useful auxiliary instances.

Example 4

The coefficients Î±Asubscriptğ›¼ğ´\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be chosen in many different ways depending on factors like relative relevance of attributes, actual distribution of data, measurement scales, etc. In the rest of this paper we will assume, for simplification, that Î±A=1subscriptğ›¼ğ´1\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}=1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 for all Aâˆˆâ„±ğ´â„±A\in{\cal F}italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_F and Î”Î±Â¯â¢(D,Dâ€²)subscriptÎ”Â¯ğ›¼ğ·superscriptğ·â€²\Delta_{\bar{\alpha}}({\it D},{\it D}^{\prime})roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) will be simply denoted by Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²\Delta({\it D},{\it D}^{\prime})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Example 5

The database Dğ·Ditalic_D has relations ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡(ğ¼ğ·,{\it Client(ID,}italic_Client ( italic_ID , A,M){\it A,M)}italic_A , italic_M ), with key ğ¼ğ·ğ¼ğ·{\it ID}italic_ID, attributes Ağ´Aitalic_A for age and Mğ‘€Mitalic_M for amount of money; and ğµğ‘¢ğ‘¦â¢(ğ¼ğ·,I,P)ğµğ‘¢ğ‘¦ğ¼ğ·ğ¼ğ‘ƒ{\it Buy(ID,I,P)}italic_Buy ( italic_ID , italic_I , italic_P ), with key {ğ¼ğ·,I}ğ¼ğ·ğ¼\{{\it ID},I\}{ italic_ID , italic_I }, Iğ¼Iitalic_I for items, and Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P for prices. 22+12+22+12=10superscript22superscript12superscript22superscript12102^{2}+1^{2}+2^{2}+1^{2}=102 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 10, and Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²â€²)=32+12=10Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²â€²superscript32superscript1210\Delta(D,D^{\prime\prime})=3^{2}+1^{2}=10roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 10. We can see that a global fix may not be the result of applying â€œlocalâ€ minimal fixes to tuples. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

The built-in atoms in linear denials determine a solution space for fixes as an intersection of semi-spaces, and LS-fixes can be found at its â€œbordersâ€ (c.f. previous example and Proposition A.0.A.1 in Appendix 0.A.1). It is easy to construct examples with an exponential number of fixes. For the kind of fixes and ICs we are considering, it is possible that no fix exists, in contrast to [3, 4], where, if the set of ICs is consistent as a set of logical sentences, a fix for a database always exist.

Example 6

Râ¢(X,Y)ğ‘…ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒR(X,Y)italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) has key Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X and fixable Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y. ğ¼ğ¶1={âˆ€X1X2YÂ¬(R(X1,Y),{\textit{IC}}_{1}=\{\forall X_{1}X_{2}Y\neg(R(X_{1},Y),IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { âˆ€ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y Â¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , R(X2,R(X_{2},italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , Y),X1=1,X2=2)Y),X_{1}\!=\!1,X_{2}\!=\!2)italic_Y ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 ), â€‹âˆ€X1X2YÂ¬(R(X1,\forall X_{1}X_{2}Y\neg(R(X_{1},âˆ€ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y Â¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , Y),Y),italic_Y ) , R(X2,Y),X1=1,X2=3)R(X_{2},Y),X_{1}\!=\!1,X_{2}\!=\!3)italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 ), âˆ€X1X2YÂ¬(\forall X_{1}X_{2}Y\neg(âˆ€ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y Â¬ ( R(X1,Y),R(X2,Y),X1=2,X2=3)R(X_{1},Y),R(X_{2},Y),\!X_{1}\!=\!2,\!X_{2}\!=\!3)italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 3 ), â€‹âˆ€Xâ¢Yâ¢Â¬â¡(Râ¢(X,Y),Y>3)for-allğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘…ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘Œ3\forall XY\neg(R(X,Y),Y\!\!>\!3)âˆ€ italic_X italic_Y Â¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_Y > 3 ), â€‹âˆ€XYÂ¬(\forall XY\neg(âˆ€ italic_X italic_Y Â¬ ( R(X,Y),Y<2)}R(X,Y),Y\!<\!2)\}italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_Y < 2 ) } is consistent. The first three ICs force Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y to be different in every tuple. The last two ICs require 2â‰¤Yâ‰¤32ğ‘Œ32\leq Y\leq 32 â‰¤ italic_Y â‰¤ 3. The inconsistent database R={(1,âˆ’1),(2,1),R=\{(1,-1),(2,1),italic_R = { ( 1 , - 1 ) , ( 2 , 1 ) , (3,5)}(3,5)\}( 3 , 5 ) } has no fix. Now, for ğ¼ğ¶2subscriptğ¼ğ¶2{\textit{IC}}_{2}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with âˆ€X,YÂ¬(R(X,Y),\forall X,Y\neg(R(X,Y),âˆ€ italic_X , italic_Y Â¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , Y>1)Y>1)italic_Y > 1 ) and ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šâ¢(Y)=10ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘Œ10{\it sum}(Y)=10italic_sum ( italic_Y ) = 10, any database with less than 10 tuples has no fixes. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proposition 1

If Dğ·Ditalic_D has a fix wrt IC, then it also has an LS-fix wrt IC. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

4 Decidability and Complexity

In applications where fixes are based on changes of numerical values, computing concrete fixes is a relevant problem. In databases containing census forms, correcting the latter before doing statistical processing is a common problem [11]. In databases with experimental samples, we can fix certain erroneous quantities as specified by linear ICs. In these cases, the fixes are relevant objects to compute explicitly, which contrasts with CQA [3], where the main motivation for introducing repairs is to formally characterize the notion of a consistent answer to a query as an answer that remains under all possible repairs. In consequence, we now consider some decision problems related to existence and verification of LS-fixes, and to CQA under different semantics.

Definition 3

For an instance Dğ·Ditalic_D and a set IC of ICs:
(a) ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶):=assignğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶absent{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}}):=italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) := {Dâ€²|Dâ€²Â is anÂ \{D^{\prime}~{}|~{}D^{\prime}~{}\mbox{ is an }{ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix ofÂ â¢DLS-fix ofÂ ğ·\mbox{LS-fix of }{\it D}LS-fix of italic_D wrtÂ ğ¼ğ¶}\mbox{wrt }{\textit{IC}}\}italic_wrt italic_IC }, the fix checking problem.
(b) ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥(ğ¼ğ¶):={(D,Dâ€²){\it Fix}({\textit{IC}}):=\{(D,D^{\prime})italic_Fix ( IC ) := { ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) |Dâ€²âˆˆğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥(D,ğ¼ğ¶)}|~{}D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})\}| italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) }.
(c)Â ğ‘ğ¸(ğ¼ğ¶):={D|{\it NE}({\textit{IC}}):=\{D~{}|italic_NE ( IC ) := { italic_D | ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) â‰ âˆ…}\neq\emptyset\}â‰  âˆ… }, for non-empty set of fixes, i.e. the problem of checking existence of LS-fixes.
(d)Â ğ‘ğ¸:={(D,ğ¼ğ¶)|ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)â‰ âˆ…}assignğ‘ğ¸conditional-setğ·ğ¼ğ¶ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶{\it NE}:=\{(D,{\textit{IC}})~{}|~{}{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})\neq\emptyset\}italic_NE := { ( italic_D , IC ) | italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) â‰  âˆ… }.
(e) ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶):={(D,k)|Â there isÂ â¢Dâ€²âˆˆFâ¢iâ¢xâ¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)â¢Â withÂ â¢Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)â‰¤k}assignğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶conditional-setğ·ğ‘˜Â there isÂ superscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶Â withÂ normal-Î”ğ·superscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ‘˜{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}})\!:=\!\!\{(D,k)|\mbox{ there is }D^{\prime}\in Fix(D,{\textit{IC}})\mbox{ with }\Delta(D,D^{\prime})\leq k\}italic_DFP ( IC ) := { ( italic_D , italic_k ) | there is italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_D , IC ) with roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_k }, the database fix problem, i.e. the problem of checking existence of LS-fixes within a given positive distance kğ‘˜kitalic_k.
(f) ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) is the optimization problem of finding the minimum distance from an LS-fix wrt IC to a given input instance. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Definition 4

Let Dğ·Ditalic_D be a database, IC a set ICs, and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q a conjunctive query222Whenever we say just â€œconjunctive queryâ€ we understand it is a non aggregate query..
(a) A ground tuple tÂ¯normal-Â¯ğ‘¡\bar{t}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG is a consistent answer to Qâ¢(xÂ¯)ğ‘„normal-Â¯ğ‘¥Q(\bar{x})italic_Q ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) under the:Â  (a1) skeptical semantics if for every Dâ€²âˆˆğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)superscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ), Dâ€²âŠ§Qâ¢(tÂ¯)modelssuperscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ‘„normal-Â¯ğ‘¡D^{\prime}\models Q(\bar{t})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Q ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ).Â  (a2) brave semantics if there exists Dâ€²âˆˆğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)superscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) with Dâ€²âŠ§Qâ¢(tÂ¯)modelssuperscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ‘„normal-Â¯ğ‘¡D^{\prime}\models Q(\bar{t})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Q ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ).Â  (a3) majority semantics if |{Dâ€²|Dâ€²âˆˆğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥(D,ğ¼ğ¶)|\{D^{\prime}~{}|~{}D^{\prime}\in{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})| { italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) and Dâ€²âŠ§modelssuperscriptğ·normal-â€²absentD^{\prime}\modelsitalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§ Q(tÂ¯)}|Q(\bar{t})\}|italic_Q ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) } | >>> |{Dâ€²|Dâ€²âˆˆ|\{D^{\prime}~{}|~{}D^{\prime}\in| { italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶{\it Fix}(D,{\textit{IC}})italic_Fix ( italic_D , IC ) and Dâ€²âŠ§Ì¸Q(tÂ¯)}|D^{\prime}\not\models Q(\bar{t})\}|italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§Ì¸ italic_Q ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) } |.
(b) That tÂ¯normal-Â¯ğ‘¡\bar{t}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG is a consistent answer to Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q in Dğ·Ditalic_D under semantics ğ’®ğ’®\cal Scaligraphic_S is denoted by DâŠ§ğ’®Qâ¢[tÂ¯]subscriptmodelsğ’®ğ·ğ‘„delimited-[]normal-Â¯ğ‘¡D\models_{\cal S}Q[\bar{t}]italic_D âŠ§ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q [ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ]. If Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is ground and DâŠ§ğ’®Qsubscriptmodelsğ’®ğ·ğ‘„D\models_{\cal S}Qitalic_D âŠ§ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q, we say that yesÂ  is a consistent answer, meaning that Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is true in the fixes of Dğ·Ditalic_D according to semantics Sğ‘†Sitalic_S. ğ¶ğ´â¢(Q,D,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ’®)ğ¶ğ´ğ‘„ğ·ğ¼ğ¶ğ’®{\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S})italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) is the set of consistent answers to Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q in Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt ICÂ under semantics ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S}caligraphic_S. For ground Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, if ğ¶ğ´â¢(Q,D,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ’®)â‰ {ğ‘¦ğ‘’ğ‘ }ğ¶ğ´ğ‘„ğ·ğ¼ğ¶ğ’®ğ‘¦ğ‘’ğ‘ {\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S})\neq\{{\it yes}\}italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) â‰  { italic_yes }, ğ¶ğ´â¢(Q,D,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ’®):={ğ‘›ğ‘œ}assignğ¶ğ´ğ‘„ğ·ğ¼ğ¶ğ’®ğ‘›ğ‘œ{\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S}):=\{{\it no}\}italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) := { italic_no }.
(c) ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´â¢(Q,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ’®):={(D,tÂ¯)|tÂ¯âˆˆğ¶ğ´â¢(Q,D,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ’®)}assignğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ‘„ğ¼ğ¶ğ’®conditional-setğ·normal-Â¯ğ‘¡normal-Â¯ğ‘¡ğ¶ğ´ğ‘„ğ·ğ¼ğ¶ğ’®{\it CQA}(Q,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S}):=\{(D,\bar{t})~{}|~{}\bar{t}\in{\it CA}(Q,D,{\textit{IC}},{\cal S})\}italic_CQA ( italic_Q , IC , caligraphic_S ) := { ( italic_D , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG âˆˆ italic_CA ( italic_Q , italic_D , IC , caligraphic_S ) } is the decision problem of consistent query answering, of checking consistent answers. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proposition 2

ğ‘ğ¸â¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ‘ğ¸ğ¼ğ¶{\it NE}({{\textit{IC}}})italic_NE ( IC ) can be reduced in polynomial time to the complements of ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´(ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’,ğ¼ğ¶,{\it CQA}({\it False},{\textit{IC}},italic_CQA ( italic_False , IC , ğ‘†ğ‘˜ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™){\it Skeptical})italic_Skeptical ) and ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´â¢(ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦)ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ¼ğ¶ğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦{\it CQA}({\it True},{\textit{IC}},{\it Majority})italic_CQA ( italic_True , IC , italic_Majority ), where ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’,ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’{\it False},{\it True}italic_False , italic_True are ground queries that are always false, resp. true. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

In Proposition 2, it suffices for queries ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’,ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’{\it False},{\it True}italic_False , italic_True to be false, resp. true, in all instances that share the key values with the input database. Then, they can be represented by âˆƒYâ¢Râ¢(cÂ¯,Y)ğ‘Œğ‘…Â¯ğ‘ğ‘Œ\exists YR(\bar{c},Y)âˆƒ italic_Y italic_R ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG , italic_Y ), where cÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{c}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG are not (for False), or are (for True) key values in the original instance.

Theorem 4.1

Under extended linear denials and complex, filtering, multi-attri-bute, single-relation, aggregation constraints, the problems ğ‘ğ¸ğ‘ğ¸{\it NE}italic_NE of existence of LS-fixes, and ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA under skeptical or majority semantics are undecidable. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

The result about ğ‘ğ¸ğ‘ğ¸{\it NE}italic_NE can be proved by reduction from the undecidable Hilbertâ€™s problem on solvability of diophantine equations. For CQA, apply Proposition 2. Here we have the original database and the set of ICs as input parameters. In the following we will be interested in data complexity, when only the input database varies and the set of ICs is fixed [2].

Theorem 4.2

For a fixed set ICÂ  of linear denials: (a) Deciding if for an instance Dğ·Ditalic_D there is an instance Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (with the same key values as Dğ·Ditalic_D) that satisfies ICÂ with Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)â‰¤knormal-Î”ğ·superscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ‘˜\Delta(D,D^{\prime})\leq kroman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_k, with positive integer kğ‘˜kitalic_k that is part of the input, is in ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP. (b) ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFP ( IC ) is ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP-complete. (c.f. Definition 3(e)) â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

By Proposition 1, there is a fix for Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC at a distance â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k iff there is an LS-fix at a distance â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k. Part (b) of Theorem 4.2 follows from part (a) and a reduction of Vertex Cover to ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶0)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ¼ğ¶0{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}}_{0})italic_DFP ( IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), for a fixed set of denials ğ¼ğ¶0subscriptğ¼ğ¶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By Theorem 4.2(a), if there is a fix at a distance â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k, the minimum distance to Dğ·Ditalic_D for a fix can be found by binary search in lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢(k)ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘˜log(k)italic_l italic_o italic_g ( italic_k ) steps. Actually, if an LS-fix exists, its square distance to Dğ·Ditalic_D is polynomially bounded by the size of Dğ·Ditalic_D (c.f. proof of Theorem 4.3). Since Dğ·Ditalic_D and a fix have the same number of tuples, only the size of their values in a fix matter, and they are constrained by a fixed set of linear denials and the condition of minimality.

Theorem 4.3

For a fixed set IC of extended linear denials: (a) The problem ğ‘ğ¸â¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ‘ğ¸ğ¼ğ¶{\it NE}({\textit{IC}})italic_NE ( IC ) of deciding if an instance has an LS-fix wrt ICÂ  is ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP-complete, and (b) ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA under the skeptical and the majority semantics is ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it coNP}italic_coNP-hard. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

For hardness in (a), (b) in Theorem 4.3, linear denials are good enough. Membership in (a) can be obtained for any fixed finite set of extended denials. Part (b) follows from part (a). The latter uses a reduction from 3-Colorability.

Theorem 4.4

For a fixed set IC of extended linear denials: (a) The problem ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ¼ğ¶{\it Fix}({\textit{IC}})italic_Fix ( IC ) of checking if an instance is an LS-fix is ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it coNP}italic_coNP-complete, and (b) ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA under skeptical semantics is in Î 2Psubscriptsuperscriptnormal-Î ğ‘ƒ2\Pi^{P}_{2}roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and, for ground atomic queries, Î”2Psuperscriptsubscriptnormal-Î”2ğ‘ƒ\Delta_{2}^{P}roman_Î” start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-hard. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Part (a) uses 3SAT. Hardness in (b) is obtained by reduction from a Î”2PsubscriptsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘ƒ2\Delta^{P}_{2}roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-complete decision version of the problem of searching for the lexicographically Maximum 3-Satisfying Assignment (M3SA): Decide if the last variable takes value 1111 in it [17, Theo. 3.4]. Linear denials suffice. Now, by reduction from the Vertex Cover Problem, we obtain

Theorem 4.5

For aggregate comparison queries using ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘š{\it sum}italic_sum, ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA under linear denials and brave semantics is ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it coNP}italic_coNP-hard. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

5 Approximation for the Database Fix Problem

We consider the problem of finding a good approximation for the general optimization problem ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ).

Proposition 3

For a fixed set of linear denials IC, ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) is ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

This result is obtained by establishing an Lğ¿Litalic_L-reduction to ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) from the ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-complete [22, 21] B-Minimum Vertex Cover Problem, i.e. the vertex cover minimization problem for graphs of bounded degree [16, Chapter 10]. As an immediate consequence, we obtain that ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) cannot be uniformly approximated within arbitrarily small constant factors [21].

Corollary 1

Unless P=ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒP\!=\!{\it NP}italic_P = italic_NP, there is no Polynomial Time Approximation Schema for ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

This negative result does not preclude the possibility of finding an efficient algorithm for approximation within a constant factor for ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP. Actually, in the following we do this for a restricted but still useful class of denial constraints.

5.1 Local denials

Definition 5

A set of linear denials ICÂ  is local if: (a) Attributes participating in equality atoms between attributes or in joins are all rigid; (b) There is a built-in atom with a fixable attribute in each element of IC; (c) No attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A appears in IC both in comparisons of the form A<c1ğ´subscriptğ‘1A<c_{1}italic_A < italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and A>c2ğ´subscriptğ‘2A>c_{2}italic_A > italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.333To check condition (c), xâ‰¤c,xâ‰¥c,xâ‰ cformulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘formulae-sequenceğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘x\leq c,~{}x\geq c,~{}x\neq citalic_x â‰¤ italic_c , italic_x â‰¥ italic_c , italic_x â‰  italic_c have to be expressed using <,><,>< , >, e.g. xâ‰¤cğ‘¥ğ‘x\leq citalic_x â‰¤ italic_c by x<c+1ğ‘¥ğ‘1x<c+1italic_x < italic_c + 1. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

In Example 5, IC is local. In Example 6, ğ¼ğ¶1subscriptğ¼ğ¶1{\textit{IC}}_{1}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not local. Local constraints have the property that by doing local fixes, no new inconsistencies are generated, and there is always an LS-fix wrt to them (c.f. Proposition A.11 in Appendix 0.A.1). Locality is a sufficient, but not necessary condition for existence of LS-fixes as can be seen from the database {Pâ¢(a,2)}ğ‘ƒğ‘2\{P(a,2)\}{ italic_P ( italic_a , 2 ) }, with the first attribute as a key and non-local denials Â¬â¡(Pâ¢(x,y),y<3),Â¬â¡(Pâ¢(x,y),y>5)ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¦3ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¦5\neg(P(x,y),y<3),\neg(P(x,y),y>5)Â¬ ( italic_P ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_y < 3 ) , Â¬ ( italic_P ( italic_x , italic_y ) , italic_y > 5 ), that has the LS-fix {Pâ¢(a,3)}ğ‘ƒğ‘3\{P(a,3)\}{ italic_P ( italic_a , 3 ) }.

Proposition 4

For the class of local denials, ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒ{\it DFP}italic_DFP is ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP-complete, and ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP is ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

This proposition tells us that the problem of finding good approximations in the case of local denials is still relevant.

Definition 6

A set Iğ¼Iitalic_I of database tuples from Dğ·Ditalic_D is a violation set for ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ¶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic âˆˆ IC if IâŠ§Ì¸ğ‘–ğ‘not-modelsğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘I\not\models{\it ic}italic_I âŠ§Ì¸ italic_ic, and for every Iâ€²â«‹Isuperscriptğ¼normal-â€²ğ¼I^{\prime}\subsetneqq Iitalic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â«‹ italic_I, Iâ€²âŠ§ğ‘–ğ‘modelssuperscriptğ¼normal-â€²ğ‘–ğ‘I^{\prime}\models{\it ic}italic_I start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_ic. â„â¢(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,t)â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) denotes the set of violation sets for ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic that contain tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

A violation set Iğ¼Iitalic_I for ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic is a minimal set of tuples that simultaneously participate in the violation of ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic.

Definition 7

Given an instance Dğ·Ditalic_D and ICs IC, a local fix for tâˆˆDğ‘¡ğ·t\in Ditalic_t âˆˆ italic_D, is a tuple tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with: (a) the same values for the rigid attributes as tğ‘¡titalic_t; (b) S(t,tâ€²):={I|there isÂ ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶,Iâˆˆâ„(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,t)Â andÂ S(t,t^{\prime}):=\{I~{}|~{}\mbox{there is }{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}},~{}I\in{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)\mbox{ and }italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) := { italic_I | there is italic_ic âˆˆ IC , italic_I âˆˆ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) and ((Iâˆ–{t})âˆª{tâ€²})âŠ§ğ‘–ğ‘}â‰ âˆ…((I\smallsetminus\{t\})\cup\{t^{\prime}\})\models{\it ic}\}~{}\neq~{}\emptyset( ( italic_I âˆ– { italic_t } ) âˆª { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) âŠ§ italic_ic } â‰  âˆ…; Â and (c) there is no tuple tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that simultaneously satisfies (a), Sâ¢(t,tâ€²â€²)=Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²S(t,t^{\prime\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²})â‰¤Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²})normal-Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²â€²normal-Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})\leq\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) â‰¤ roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ), where Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î” denotes quadratic distance. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) contains the violation sets that include tğ‘¡titalic_t and are solved by replacing tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for tğ‘¡titalic_t. A local fix tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT solves some of the violations due to tğ‘¡titalic_t and minimizes the distance to tğ‘¡titalic_t.

5.2 Database fix problem as a set cover problem

For a fixed set IC of local denials, we can solve an instance of ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP by transforming it into an instance of the Minimum Weighted Set Cover Optimization Problem (ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ\!{\it MWSCP}\!italic_MWSCP). This problem is ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard [20, 21], and its general approximation algorithms are within a logarithmic factor [20, 9]. By concentrating on local denials, we will be able to generate a version of the ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP that can be approximated within a constant factor (c.f. Section 5.3).

Definition 8

For a database Dğ·Ditalic_D and a set IC of local denials, ğ’¢â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)=(T,H)ğ’¢ğ·ğ¼ğ¶ğ‘‡ğ»{\cal G}(D,{\textit{IC}})=(T,H)caligraphic_G ( italic_D , IC ) = ( italic_T , italic_H ) denotes the conflict hypergraph for Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC [8], which has in the set Tğ‘‡Titalic_T of vertices the database tuples, and in the set Hğ»Hitalic_H of hyperedges, the violation sets for elements ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ¶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic âˆˆ IC. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Hyperedges in Hğ»Hitalic_H can be labelled with the corresponding ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic, so that different hyperedges may contain the same tuples. Now we build an instance of ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ\!{\it MWSCP}\!italic_MWSCP.

Definition 9

For a database Dğ·Ditalic_D and a set IC of local denials, the instance (U,ğ’®,w)ğ‘ˆğ’®ğ‘¤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) for the ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ\!{\it MWSCP}\!italic_MWSCP, where Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U is the underlying set, ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S}caligraphic_S is the set collection, and wğ‘¤witalic_w is the weight function, is given by: (a) U:=Hassignğ‘ˆğ»U:=Hitalic_U := italic_H, the set of hyperedges of ğ’¢â¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)ğ’¢ğ·ğ¼ğ¶{\cal G}(D,{\textit{IC}})caligraphic_G ( italic_D , IC ). (b) ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S}caligraphic_S contains the Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a local fix for a tuple tâˆˆDğ‘¡ğ·t\in Ditalic_t âˆˆ italic_D. (c) wâ¢(Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)):=Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²})assignğ‘¤ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²normal-Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²w(S(t,t^{\prime})):=\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})italic_w ( italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) := roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

It can be proved that the Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in this construction are non empty, and that ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S}caligraphic_S covers Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U (c.f. Proposition A.11 in Appendix 0.A.1).

If for the instance (U,ğ’®,w)ğ‘ˆğ’®ğ‘¤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP we find a minimum weight cover ğ’ğ’\cal Ccaligraphic_C, we could think of constructing a fix by replacing each inconsistent tuple tâˆˆDğ‘¡ğ·t\in Ditalic_t âˆˆ italic_D by a local fix tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)âˆˆğ’ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ’S(t,t^{\prime})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_C. The problem is that there might be more than one tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the key dependencies would not be respected. Fortunately, this problem can be circumvented.

Definition 10

Let ğ’ğ’{\cal C}caligraphic_C be a cover for instance (U,ğ’®,w)ğ‘ˆğ’®ğ‘¤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of the ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP associated to It holds (c.f. Notice that there, tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t could have other Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) outside ğ’ğ’{\cal C}caligraphic_C. Now we can show that the reduction to ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP keeps the value of the objective function.

Proposition 5

If ğ’ğ’{\cal C}caligraphic_C is an optimal cover for instance (U,ğ’®,w)ğ‘ˆğ’®ğ‘¤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of the ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP associated to D,ğ¼ğ¶ğ·ğ¼ğ¶D,{\textit{IC}}italic_D , IC, then Dâ¢(ğ’)ğ·ğ’D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) is an LS-fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC, and Î”â¢(D,Dâ¢(ğ’))=wâ¢(ğ’)=wâ¢(ğ’*)normal-Î”ğ·ğ·ğ’ğ‘¤ğ’ğ‘¤superscriptğ’\Delta(D,D({\cal C}))=w({\cal C})=w({\cal C}^{*})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) ) = italic_w ( caligraphic_C ) = italic_w ( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proposition 6

For every LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt a set of local denials IC, there exists an optimal cover ğ’ğ’\cal Ccaligraphic_C for the associated instance (U,ğ’®,w)ğ‘ˆğ’®ğ‘¤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) of the Mâ¢Wâ¢Sâ¢Câ¢Pğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒMWSCPitalic_M italic_W italic_S italic_C italic_P, such that Dâ€²=Dâ¢(ğ’)superscriptğ·normal-â€²ğ·ğ’D^{\prime}=D({\cal C})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D ( caligraphic_C ). â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proposition 7

The transformation of ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP into ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP, and the construction of database instance Dâ¢(ğ’)ğ·ğ’D({\cal C})italic_D ( caligraphic_C ) from a cover ğ’ğ’{\cal C}caligraphic_C for (U,ğ’®,w)ğ‘ˆğ’®ğ‘¤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ) can be done in polynomial time in the size of Dğ·Ditalic_D. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

We have established that the transformation of ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP into ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP is an Lğ¿Litalic_L-reduction [21]. Proposition 7 proves, in particular, that the number of violation sets Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is polynomially bounded by the size of the original database Dğ·Ditalic_D.

Example 7

(example 5 continued) We illustrate the reduction from ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP to ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP. The violation sets are {t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,t4subscriptğ‘¡4t_{4}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} and {t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,t5subscriptğ‘¡5t_{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} for ğ¼ğ¶1subscriptğ¼ğ¶1{\it IC}_{1}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and {t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} and {t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT} for ğ¼ğ¶2subscriptğ¼ğ¶2{\it IC}_{2}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The figure shows the hypergraph. For the ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP instance, we need the local fixes. Tuple t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has two local fixes t1â€²=(1,15,50)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1â€²11550t_{1}^{\prime}=(1,15,50)italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 1 , 15 , 50 ), that solves the violation set {t1}subscriptğ‘¡1\{t_{1}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of ğ¼ğ¶2subscriptğ¼ğ¶2{\textit{IC}}_{2}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (hyperedge B), and t1â€²â€²=(1,18,52)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1â€²â€²11852t_{1}^{\prime\prime}=(1,18,52)italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 1 , 18 , 52 ), that solves the violation sets {t1,t4}subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡4\{t_{1},t_{4}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and {t1,t5}subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡5\{t_{1},t_{5}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of ğ¼ğ¶1subscriptğ¼ğ¶1{\it IC}_{1}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and {t1}subscriptğ‘¡1\{t_{1}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of ğ¼ğ¶2subscriptğ¼ğ¶2{\it IC}_{2}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (hyperedges A,B, C), with weights 4444 and 9999, resp. t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, t4subscriptğ‘¡4t_{4}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and t5subscriptğ‘¡5t_{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have one local fix each corresponding to: (2,16,50)21650(2,16,50)( 2 , 16 , 50 ), (1,ğ¶ğ·,25)1ğ¶ğ·25(1,{\it CD},25)( 1 , italic_CD , 25 ) and (1,ğ·ğ‘‰ğ·,25)1ğ·ğ‘‰ğ·25(1,{\it DVD},25)( 1 , italic_DVD , 25 ), resp. Â The consistent tuple t3subscriptğ‘¡3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has no local fix.
