The ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP instance is shown in the table, where the elements are rows and the sets (e.g. S1=Sâ¢(t1,t1â€²)subscriptğ‘†1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1â€²S_{1}=S(t_{1},t_{1}^{\prime})italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_S ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )), columns. An entry 1111 means that the set contains the corresponding element; and a 00, otherwise. There are two minimal covers, both with weight 10101010: ğ’1={S2,S3}subscriptğ’1subscriptğ‘†2subscriptğ‘†3{\cal C}_{1}=\{S_{2},S_{3}\}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and ğ’2={S1,S3,S4,S5}subscriptğ’2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†3subscriptğ‘†4subscriptğ‘†5{\cal C}_{2}=\{S_{1},S_{3},S_{4},S_{5}\}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Dâ¢(ğ’1)ğ·subscriptğ’1D({\cal C}_{1})italic_D ( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Dâ¢(ğ’2)ğ·subscriptğ’2D({\cal C}_{2})italic_D ( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are the two fixes for this problem. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

If we apply the transformation to Example 6, that had non-local set of ICs and no repairs, we will find that instance Dâ¢(ğ’)ğ·ğ’D(\cal C)italic_D ( caligraphic_C ), for ğ’ğ’{\cal C}caligraphic_C a set cover, can be constructed as above, but it does not satisfy the flexible ICs, because changing inconsistent tuples by their local fixes solves only the initial inconsistencies, but new inconsistencies are introduced.

5.3 Approximation via set cover optimization

Now that we have transformed the database fix problem into a weighted set cover problem, we can apply approximation algorithms for the latter. We know, for example, that using a greedy algorithm, ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP can be approximated within a factor ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”â¢(N)ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘{\it log}(N)italic_log ( italic_N ), where Nğ‘Nitalic_N is the size of the underlying set Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U [9]. The approximation algorithm returns not only an approximation w^^ğ‘¤\hat{w}over^ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG to the optimal weight wosuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘œw^{o}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, but also a -non necessarily optimal- cover ğ’^^ğ’\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG for problem (U,ğ’®,w)ğ‘ˆğ’®ğ‘¤(U,{\cal S},w)( italic_U , caligraphic_S , italic_w ). As in Definition 10, ğ’^^ğ’\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG can be used to generate via (ğ’^)â‹†superscript^ğ’â‹†(\hat{\cal C})^{\star}( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a fix Dâ¢(ğ’^)ğ·^ğ’D(\hat{\cal C})italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) for Dğ·Ditalic_D that may not be LS-minimal.

Example 8

(examples 5 and 7 continued) We show how to to compute a solution to this particular instance of ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP using the greedy approximation algorithm for ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP presented in [9]. We start with ğ’^:=âˆ…assign^ğ’{\cal\hat{C}}:=\emptysetover^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG := âˆ…, Si0:=Siassignsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}^{0}:=S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; and we add to ğ’ğ’\cal Ccaligraphic_C the Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Si0superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–0S_{i}^{0}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has the maximum contribution ratio |Si0|/wâ¢(Si0)superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–0ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–0|S_{i}^{0}|/w(S_{i}^{0})| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | / italic_w ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). The alternatives are |S1|/wâ¢(S1)=1/4subscriptğ‘†1ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘†114|S_{1}|/w(S_{1})=1/4| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | / italic_w ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 / 4, |S2|/wâ¢(S2)=3/9subscriptğ‘†2ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘†239|S_{2}|/w(S_{2})=3/9| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | / italic_w ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 3 / 9, |S3|/wâ¢(S3)=1subscriptğ‘†3ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘†31|S_{3}|/w(S_{3})=1| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | / italic_w ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1, |S4|/wâ¢(S4)=1/4subscriptğ‘†4ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘†414|S_{4}|/w(S_{4})=1/4| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | / italic_w ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 / 4 and |S5|/wâ¢(S5)=1subscriptğ‘†5ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘†51|S_{5}|/w(S_{5})=1| italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | / italic_w ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1. The ratio is maximum for S3subscriptğ‘†3S_{3}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S5subscriptğ‘†5S_{5}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so we can add any of them to ğ’^^ğ’\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG. If we choose the first, we get ğ’^={S3}^ğ’subscriptğ‘†3{\cal\hat{C}}=\{S_{3}\}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Now we compute the Si1:=Si0âˆ–S30assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘†30S_{i}^{1}:=S_{i}^{0}\smallsetminus S_{3}^{0}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and choose again an Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for ğ’^^ğ’\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG such that Si1superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–1S_{i}^{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT maximizes the contribution ratio. Now S5subscriptğ‘†5S_{5}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is added to ğ’^^ğ’\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG, because S51superscriptsubscriptğ‘†51S_{5}^{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT gives the maximum. By repeating this process until we get all the elements of Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U covered, i.e. all the Siksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘˜S_{i}^{k}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT become empty at some iteration point kğ‘˜kitalic_k, we finally obtain ğ’^={S3,S5,S1,S4}^ğ’subscriptğ‘†3subscriptğ‘†5subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†4\hat{\cal C}=\{S_{3},S_{5},S_{1},S_{4}\}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. In this case ğ’^^ğ’{\cal\hat{C}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG is an optimal cover and therefore, Dâ¢(ğ’^)ğ·^ğ’D({\cal\hat{C}})italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) is exactly an LS-fix, namely Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Example 5. Since this is an approximation algorithm, in other examples the cover obtained might not be optimal. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proposition 8

Given database instance Dğ·Ditalic_D with local ICs IC, the database instance Dâ¢(ğ’^)ğ·normal-^ğ’D(\hat{\cal C})italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) obtained from the approximate cover ğ’^normal-^ğ’\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG is a fix and it holds Î”â¢(D,Dâ¢(ğ’^))â‰¤lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢(N)Ã—Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)normal-Î”ğ·ğ·normal-^ğ’ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘normal-Î”ğ·superscriptğ·normal-â€²\Delta(D,D(\hat{\cal C}))\leq log(N)\times\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) ) â‰¤ italic_l italic_o italic_g ( italic_N ) Ã— roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is any LS-fix of D wrt IC and Nğ‘Nitalic_N is the number of of violation sets for Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

In consequence, for any set IC of local denials, we have a polynomial time approximation algorithm that solves ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¼ğ¶{\it DFOP}({\textit{IC}})italic_DFOP ( IC ) within an Oâ¢(ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”â¢(N))ğ‘‚ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘O({\it log}(N))italic_O ( italic_log ( italic_N ) ) factor, where Nğ‘Nitalic_N is the number of violation sets for Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC. As mentioned before, this number Nğ‘Nitalic_N, the number of hyperedges in ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G}caligraphic_G, is polynomially bounded by |D|ğ·|D|| italic_D | (c.f. Proposition 7). Nğ‘Nitalic_N may be small if the number of inconsistencies or the number of database atoms in the ICs are small, which is likely the case in real applications.

However, in our case we can get even better approximations via a cover ğ’^^ğ’\hat{\cal C}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG obtained with an approximation algorithms for the special case of the ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP where the number of occurrences of an element of Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U in elements of ğ’®ğ’®{\cal S}caligraphic_S is bounded by a constant. For this case of the ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP there are approximations within a constant factor based on â€œlinear relaxationâ€ [16, Chapter 3]. This is clearly the case in our application, being mÃ—|â„±|Ã—|ğ¼ğ¶|ğ‘šâ„±ğ¼ğ¶m\times|{\cal F}|\times|{\it IC}|italic_m Ã— | caligraphic_F | Ã— | italic_IC | a constant bound (independent from |D|ğ·|D|| italic_D |) on the frequency of the elements, where mğ‘šmitalic_m is the maximum number of database atoms in an IC.

Theorem 5.1

There is an approximation algorithm that, for a given database instance Dğ·Ditalic_D with local ICs IC, returns a fix Dâ¢(ğ’^)ğ·normal-^ğ’D(\hat{\cal C})italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) such that Î”â¢(D,Dâ¢(ğ’^))â‰¤cÃ—Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)normal-Î”ğ·ğ·normal-^ğ’ğ‘normal-Î”ğ·superscriptğ·normal-â€²\Delta(D,D(\hat{\cal C}))\leq c\times\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) ) â‰¤ italic_c Ã— roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where cğ‘citalic_c is a constant and Dâ€²superscriptğ·normal-â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is any LS-fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

6 One Atoms Denials and Conjunctive Queries

In this section we concentrate on the common case of one database atom denials (1AD), i.e. of the form âˆ€Â¬â¡(A,B)for-allğ´ğµ\forall\neg(A,B)âˆ€ Â¬ ( italic_A , italic_B ), where atom Ağ´Aitalic_A has a predicate in â„›â„›{\cal R}caligraphic_R, and BğµBitalic_B is a conjunction of built-in atoms. They capture range constraints; and census data is usually stored in single relation schemas [11].

For 1ADs, we can identify tractable cases for ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA under LS-fixes by reduction to ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA for (tuple and set-theoretic) repairs of the form introduced in [3] for key constraints. This is because each violation set (c.f. Definition 6) contains one tuple, maybe with several local fixes, but all sharing the same key values; and then the problem consists in choosing one from different tuples with the same key values (c.f. proof of Theorem 6.1). The transformation preserves consistent answers to both ground and open queries.

The â€œclassicalâ€ -tuple and set oriented- repair problem as introduced in [3] has been studied in detail for functional dependencies in [8, 12]. In particular, for tractability of ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA in our setting, we can use results and algorithms obtained in [12] for the classical framework.

The join graph ğ’¢â¢(Q)ğ’¢ğ‘„{\cal G}(Q)caligraphic_G ( italic_Q ) [12] of a conjunctive query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is a directed graph, whose vertices are the database atoms in Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. There is an arc from Lğ¿Litalic_L to Lâ€²superscriptğ¿â€²L^{\prime}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if Lâ‰ Lâ€²ğ¿superscriptğ¿â€²L\neq L^{\prime}italic_L â‰  italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and there is a variable wğ‘¤witalic_w that occurs at the position of a non-key attribute in Lğ¿Litalic_L and also occurs in Lâ€²superscriptğ¿â€²L^{\prime}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Furthermore, there is a self-loop at Lğ¿Litalic_L if there is a variable that occurs at the position of a non-key attribute in Lğ¿Litalic_L, and at least twice in Lğ¿Litalic_L.

When Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q does not have repeated relations symbols, we write Qâˆˆğ’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’ğ‘„subscriptğ’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’Q\in{\cal C}_{\!\it Tree}italic_Q âˆˆ caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if ğ’¢â¢(Q)ğ’¢ğ‘„{\cal G}(Q)caligraphic_G ( italic_Q ) is a forest and every non-key to key join of Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is full i.e. involves the whole key. Classical ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA is tractable for queries in ğ’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’subscriptğ’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’{\cal C}_{\!\it Tree}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [12].

Theorem 6.1

For a fixed set of 1ADs and queries in Cğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’C_{\!{\it Tree}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, consistent query answering under LS-fixes is in ğ‘ƒğ‘‡ğ¼ğ‘€ğ¸ğ‘ƒğ‘‡ğ¼ğ‘€ğ¸{\it PTIME}italic_PTIME. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

We may define that a aggregate conjunctive query belongs to Cğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’C_{\!{\it Tree}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if its underlying non-aggregate conjunctive query, i.e. its NAM (c.f. Section 2) belongs to Cğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’C_{\!{\it Tree}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Even for 1ADs, with simple comparison aggregate queries with ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘š{\it sum}italic_sum, tractability is lost under the brave semantics.

Proposition 9

For a fixed set of 1ADs, and for aggregate queries that are in Cğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’subscriptğ¶ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’C_{\!{\it Tree}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or acyclic, ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA is ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP-hard under the brave semantics. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

For queries Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q returning numerical values, which is common in our framework, it is natural to use the range semantics for ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA, introduced in [4] for scalar aggregate queries and functional dependencies under classical repairs. Under this semantics, a consistent answer is the pair consisting of the min-max and max-min answers, i.e. the supremum and the infimum, resp., of the set of answers to Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q obtained from LS-fixes. The ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA decision problems under range semantics consist in determining if a numerical query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, e.g. an aggregate query, has its answer â‰¤k1absentsubscriptğ‘˜1\leq k_{1}â‰¤ italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in every fix (min-max case), or â‰¥k2absentsubscriptğ‘˜2\geq k_{2}â‰¥ italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in every fix (max-min case).

Theorem 6.2

For each of the aggregate functions sum, count distinct, and average, there is a fixed set of 1ADs and a fixed aggregate acyclic conjunctive query, such that ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´{\it CQA}italic_CQA under the range semantics is ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP-hard. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

For the three aggregate functions one 1AD suffices. The results for count distinct and average are obtained by reduction from ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ´ğ‘‡ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ´ğ‘‡{\it MAXSAT}italic_MAXSAT [21] and 3â¢Sâ¢Aâ¢T3ğ‘†ğ´ğ‘‡{\it 3SAT}italic_3 italic_S italic_A italic_T, resp. For sum, we use a reduction from the Independent Set Problem with bounded degree 3 [14]. The general Independent Set Problem has bad approximation properties [16, Chapter 10]. The Bounded Degree Independent Set has efficient approximations within a constant factor that depends on the degree [15].

Theorem 6.3

For any set of 1ADs and conjunctive query with sum over a non-negative attribute, there is a polynomial time approximation algorithm with a constant factor for CQA under min-max range semantics. â–¡normal-â–¡\Boxâ–¡

The factor in this theorem depends upon the ICs and the query, but not on the size of the database. The acyclicity of the query is not required. The algorithm is based on a reduction of our problem to satisfying a subsystem with maximum weight of a system of weighted algebraic equations over the Galois field with two elements ğºğ¹â¢[2]ğºğ¹delimited-[]2{\it GF}[2]italic_GF [ 2 ] (a generalization of problems in [13, 24]), for which a polynomial time approximation similar to the one for MAXSAT can be given [24].

7 Conclusions

We have shown that fixing numerical values in databases poses many new computational challenges that had not been addressed before in the context of consistent query answering. These problems are particularly relevant in census like applications, where the problem of data editing is a common and difficult task (c.f. http://www.unece.org/stats/documents/2005.05.sde.htm). Also our concentration on aggregate queries is particularly relevant for this kind of statistical applications. In this paper we have just started to investigate some of the many problems that appear in this context, and several extensions are in development. We concentrated on integer numerical values, which provide a useful and challenging domain. Considering real numbers in fixable attributes opens many new issues, requires different approaches; and is a subject of ongoing research.

The framework established in this paper could be applied to qualitative attributes with an implicit linear order given by the application. The result we have presented for fixable attributes that are all equally relevant (Î±A=1subscriptğ›¼ğ´1\alpha_{\!{}_{A}}=1italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 in Definitions 1 and 2) should carry over without much difficulty to the general case of arbitrary weighted fixes. We have developed (but not reported here) extensions to our approach that consider minimum distribution variation LS-fixes that keep the overall statistical properties of the database. We have also developed optimizations of the approximation algorithm presented in Section 5; and its implementation and experiments are ongoing efforts. More research on the impact of aggregation constraints on LS-fixes is needed.

Of course, if instead of the L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distance, the L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT distance is used, we may get for the same database a different set of (now L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) fixes. The actual approximations obtained in this paper change too. However, the general complexity and approximability results should remain. They basically depend on the fact that distance functions are non-negative, additive wrt attributes and tuples, computable in polynomial time, and monotonically increasing. Another possible semantics could consider an epsilon of error in the distance in such a way that if, for example, the distance of a fix is 5555 and the distance to another fix is 5.0015.0015.0015.001, we could take both of them as (minimal) LS-fixes.

Other open problems refer to cases of polynomial complexity for linear denials with more that one database atom; approximation algorithms for the DFOP for non-local cases; and approximations to CQA for other aggregate queries.

For related work, we refer to the literature on consistent query answering (c.f. [5] for a survey and references). Papers [25] and [11] are the closest to our work, because changes in attribute values are basic repair actions, but the peculiarities of numerical values and quantitative distances between databases are not investigated. Under the set-theoretic, tuple-based semantics, [8, 7, 12] report on complexity issues for conjunctive queries, functional dependencies and foreign key constraints. A majority semantics was studied in [19] for database merging. Quite recent papers, but under semantics different than ours, report research on fixing numerical values under aggregation constraints [10]; and heuristic construction of repairs based on attribute values changes [6].

  • [7] Cali, A., Lembo, D., Rosati, R. On the Decidability and Complexity of Query Answering over Inconsistent and Incomplete Databases. In Proc. ACM Symposium on Principles of Database Systems (PODS 03), 2003, pp. 260-271.
  • [8] Chomicki, J. and Marcinkowski, J. Minimal-Change Integrity Maintenance Using Tuple Deletions. Information and Computation, 2005, 197(1-2):90-121.
  • [9] Chvatal, V. A Greedy Heuristic for the Set Covering Problem. Mathematics of Operations Research, 1979, 4:233-235.
  • [10] Flesca, S., Furfaro, F. and Parisi, F. Consistent Query Answers on Numerical Databases under Aggregate Constraints. In Proc. Tenth International Symposium on Database Programming Languages (DBPL 05), 2005.
  • [11] Franconi, E., Laureti Palma, A., Leone, N., Perri, S. and Scarcello, F. Census Data Repair: a Challenging Application of Disjunctive Logic Programming. In Proc. Logic for Programming, Artificial Intelligence, and Reasoning (LPAR 01). Springer LNCS 2250, 2001, pp. 561-578.
  • [12] Fuxman, A. and Miller, R. First-Order Query Rewriting for Inconsistent Databases. In Proc. International Conference on Database Theory (ICDT 05), Springer LNCS 3363, 2004, pp. 337-354.
  • [13] Garey, M.R. and Johnson, D.S. Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness. W.H. Freeman and Co., 1979.
  • [14] Garey, M., Johnson, D. and Stockmeyer, L. Some Simplified NP-Complete Graph Problems. Theoretical Computer Science, 1976, 1(3):237-267.
  • [15] Halldorsson, M. and Radhakrishnan, J. Greed is Good: Approximating Independent Sets in Sparse and Bounded-degree Graphs. In Proc. ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (SToC 94), 1994, pp. 439-448.
  • [16] Hochbaum, D.(ed.) Approximation Algorithms for NP-Hard Problems. PWS, 1997.
  • [17] Krentel, M. The Complexity of Optimization Problems. J. Computer and Systems Sciences, 1988, 36:490-509.
  • [18] Kuper, G., Libkin, L. and Paredaens, J.(eds.) Constraint Databases. Springer, 2000.
  • [19] Lin, J. and Mendelzon, A.O. Merging Databases under Constraints. International Journal of Cooperative Information Systems, 1996, 7(1):55-76.
  • [20] Lund, C. and Yannakakis, M. On the Hardness of Approximating Minimization Problems. J. of the Association for Computing Machinery, 1994, 45(5):960-981.
  • [21] Papadimitriou, Ch. Computational Complexity. Addison-Wesley, 1994.
  • [22] Papadimitriou, Ch. and Yannakakis, M. Optimization, Approximation and Complexity Classes. J. Computer and Systems Sciences, 1991, 43:425-440.
  • [23] Ross, K., Srivastava, D., Stuckey, P., and Sudarshan, S.. Foundations of Aggregation Constraints. Theoretical Computer Science, 1998, 193(1-2):149â€“179.

Appendix 0.A Appendix

0.A.1 Proofs

Those auxiliary technical results that are stated in this appendix, but not in the main body of the paper, are numbered in the form ğ€.ğ§formulae-sequenceğ€ğ§{\bf A.n}bold_A . bold_n, e.g. Lemma A.1.

Proof of Proposition 1:Â Let ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï be the square distance between Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Definition 1. The circle of radius ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï around Dğ·Ditalic_D intersects the non empty â€œconsistentâ€ region that contains the database instances with the same schema and key values as Dğ·Ditalic_D and satisfy IC. Since the circle has a finite number of instances, the distance takes a minimum in the consistent region. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

The following lemma proves that if a tuple is involved in an inconsistency, the set of constraints is consistent and there is at least one fixable attribute in each integrity constraint, then there always exists a local fix (see Definition 7) for it.


Lemma A.1. For a database Dğ·Ditalic_D and a consistent set of linear denial constraints IC, where each constraint contains at least one built-in involving a flexible constraint and there are equalities or joins only between rigid attributes. Then, for every tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t with at least one fixable attribute and at least one ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic in IC, â„â¢(D,iâ¢c,t)â‰ âˆ…â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡{\cal I}(D,ic,t)\neq\emptysetcaligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_i italic_c , italic_t ) â‰  âˆ…, there exists at least one local fix tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see Definition 7) â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof:Â  Each constraint ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ¶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic âˆˆ IC has the form âˆ€xÂ¯Â¬(P1(xÂ¯),â€¦,\forall\bar{x}\neg(P_{1}(\bar{x}),\ldots,âˆ€ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG Â¬ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) , â€¦ , Pnâ¢(xÂ¯),subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›Â¯ğ‘¥P_{n}(\bar{x}),italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) , Ai<ci,Ajâ‰¥cj,Ak=ck,Alâ‰ cl,â€¦)A_{i}<c_{i},A_{j}\geq c_{j},A_{k}=c_{k},A_{l}\neq c_{l},\ldots)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ ) and can be rewritten as a clause only with <<<, >>> and ===:

âˆ€xÂ¯â¢(Â¬â¢P1â¢(xÂ¯)âˆ¨â€¦âˆ¨Â¬â¢Pnâ¢(xÂ¯)âˆ¨Aiâ‰¥ciâˆ¨Aj<cjâˆ¨Akâ¢<ckâˆ¨Ak>â¢ckâˆ¨Al=clâˆ¨â€¦)for-allÂ¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ƒ1Â¯ğ‘¥â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ´ğ‘˜expectationsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ´ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ´ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘™â€¦\forall\bar{x}(\neg P_{1}(\bar{x})\vee\ldots\vee\neg P_{n}(\bar{x})\vee A_{i}\geq c_{i}\vee A_{j}<c_{j}\vee A_{k}<c_{k}\vee A_{k}>c_{k}\vee A_{l}=c_{l}\vee\ldots)âˆ€ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ( Â¬ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) âˆ¨ â€¦ âˆ¨ Â¬ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ â€¦ ) (1)

This formula shows that since the repairs are done by attributes updates, the only way we have of solving an inconsistency is by fixing at least one of the values of a fixable attribute. Let ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic be a constraint in IC such that â„â¢(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,t)â‰ âˆ…â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)\neq\emptysetcaligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) â‰  âˆ… and Iğ¼Iitalic_I be a violation set Iâˆˆâ„â¢(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,t)ğ¼â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡I\in{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)italic_I âˆˆ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ). Now, since ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ¶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic âˆˆ IC, ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic is a consistent constraints. Then for each fixable attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A in ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic we are able to derive an interval [cl,cu]subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢[c_{l},c_{u}][ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] such that if the value of Ağ´Aitalic_A is in it, we would restore the consistency of Iğ¼Iitalic_I. For example if we have a constraint in form of equation (1) with Aâ‰¤5ğ´5A\leq 5italic_A â‰¤ 5, then, if we want to restore consistency by modifying Ağ´Aitalic_A we would need to have Aâˆˆ(âˆ’âˆ,5]ğ´5A\in~{}(-\infty,5]italic_A âˆˆ ( - âˆ , 5 ]. If the constraint had also Aâ‰¥1ğ´1A\geq 1italic_A â‰¥ 1 the interval would be [1,5]15[1,5][ 1 , 5 ]. Since tğ‘¡titalic_t has at least one fixable attribute and each fixable attribute has an interval, it is always possible to adjust the value of that fixable attribute to a value in the interval [cl,cu]subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢[c_{l},c_{u}][ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] and restore consistency. By finding the adjustment that minimizes the distance from the original tuple we have find a local fix for the tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

The borders of an attribute in an extended linear denial correspond to the surfaces of the semi-spaces determined by the built-in atoms in it.


Proposition A.1. Given a database Dğ·Ditalic_D and a set of linear denials IC, where equalities and joins can only exist between rigid attributes, the values in every fixable attributes in a local fix tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (c.f. Definition 7) of a tuple tâˆˆDğ‘¡ğ·t\in Ditalic_t âˆˆ italic_D will correspond to the original value in tğ‘¡titalic_t or to a border of a constraint in IC. Furthermore, the values in every attributes of a tuple tâ€²âˆˆDâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²superscriptğ·â€²t^{\prime}\in D^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will correspond to the original value of the attribute in the tuple in Dğ·Ditalic_D or to a border of a constraint in IC. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof:Â First we will replace in all the constraints Xâ‰¤cğ‘‹ğ‘X\leq citalic_X â‰¤ italic_c by X<(c+1)ğ‘‹ğ‘1X<(c+1)italic_X < ( italic_c + 1 ), Xâ‰¥cğ‘‹ğ‘X\geq citalic_X â‰¥ italic_c by X>(câˆ’1)ğ‘‹ğ‘1X>(c-1)italic_X > ( italic_c - 1 ) and X=cğ‘‹ğ‘X=citalic_X = italic_c by (X>(câˆ’1)âˆ§X<(c+1))ğ‘‹ğ‘1ğ‘‹ğ‘1(X>(c-1)\wedge X<(c+1))( italic_X > ( italic_c - 1 ) âˆ§ italic_X < ( italic_c + 1 ) ). We can do this because we are dealing with integer values. Then, a constraint ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic would have the form âˆ€xÂ¯Â¬(P1(xÂ¯),â€¦,Pn(xÂ¯),\forall\bar{x}\neg(P_{1}(\bar{x}),\ldots,P_{n}(\bar{x}),âˆ€ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG Â¬ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) , â€¦ , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) , Ai<ci,Aj>cj,Akâ‰ ck,â€¦)A_{i}<c_{i},A_{j}>c_{j},A_{k}\neq c_{k},\ldots)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ ) and can be rewritten as

âˆ€xÂ¯â¢(Â¬â¢P1â¢(xÂ¯)âˆ¨â€¦âˆ¨Â¬â¢Pnâ¢(xÂ¯)âˆ¨Aiâ‰¥ciâˆ¨Ajâ‰¤cjâˆ¨Ak=ckâˆ¨â€¦)for-allÂ¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ƒ1Â¯ğ‘¥â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ´ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ´ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ´ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜â€¦\forall\bar{x}(\neg P_{1}(\bar{x})\vee\ldots\vee\neg P_{n}(\bar{x})\vee A_{i}\geq c_{i}\vee A_{j}\leq c_{j}\vee A_{k}=c_{k}\vee\ldots)âˆ€ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ( Â¬ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) âˆ¨ â€¦ âˆ¨ Â¬ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ â€¦ ) (2)

This formula shows that since the repairs are done by attributes updates, the only way we have of solving an inconsistency is by fixing at least one of the values of a fixable attribute. This would imply to change the value of a fixable attribute Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to something equal or greater than cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to change the value of a fixable attribute Ajsubscriptğ´ğ‘—A_{j}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to a value equal or smaller than cjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—c_{j}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or to change the value of attribute Aksubscriptğ´ğ‘˜A_{k}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to cksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜c_{k}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

If Dğ·Ditalic_D is consistent wrt IC then there is a unique LS-fix Dâ€²=Dsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ·D^{\prime}=Ditalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D and all the values are the same as the original ones and therefore the proposition holds. If Dğ·Ditalic_D is inconsistent wrt IC then there exists a tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t with at least one fixable attribute and a set ğ¼ğ¶tâŠ†ğ¼ğ¶subscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡ğ¼ğ¶{\textit{IC}}_{t}\subseteq{\textit{IC}}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† IC such that for every ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶tğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}_{t}italic_ic âˆˆ IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it holds â„â¢(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,t)â‰ âˆ…â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)\neq\emptysetcaligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) â‰  âˆ…. If ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an inconsistent set of constraints then there exists no local fix and the proposition holds. If ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is consistent but there is at least one constraint with no fixable attributes involved then, since it is not possible to modify any attribute in order to satisfy the constraint, there is no local fix and the proposition holds.

So we are only missing to prove the proposition for ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT consistent and with at least one fixable attributes for each ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic in ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. From Lemma A.0.A.1 we know that there exists a local fix for tğ‘¡titalic_t. Also, since ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is consistent, using the same arguments as in proof of Lemma A.0.A.1, it is possible to define for each fixable attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A an interval such that if the value of Ağ´Aitalic_A is in it we would restore the consistency of the violation sets for constraints in ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT involving tğ‘¡titalic_t. Then, we need to prove that if a value of an attribute, say Ağ´Aitalic_A, of a local fix tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of tğ‘¡titalic_t is different than the one in tğ‘¡titalic_t, then the value corresponds to one of the closed limits of the interval for Ağ´Aitalic_A. Let us assume that an attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A is restricted by the constraints to an interval [cl,cu]subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘¢[c_{l},c_{u}][ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] and that the local fix tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT takes for attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A a value strictly smaller than cusubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢c_{u}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and strictly greater than clsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™c_{l}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Without lost of generality we will assume that the value of attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A in tğ‘¡titalic_t is bigger than cusubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢c_{u}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a tuple with the same values as tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT except that the attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A is set to cusubscriptğ‘ğ‘¢c_{u}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will have the same values in the rigid attributes as tğ‘¡titalic_t and also Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)=Sâ¢(t,tâ€²â€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²S(t,t^{\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) since the value of Ağ´Aitalic_A in tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is still in the interval. We also have that Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²})â‰¤Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²})Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})\leq\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) â‰¤ roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). This implies that tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not a local fix and we have reached a contradiction.

For the second part of the proposition, the proof of the first part can be easily extended to prove that the values in Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will correspond to a border of a constraint in IC, because the LS-fixes are combination of local fixes. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Theorem 4.1:Â Hilbertâ€™s 10th problem on existence of integer solutions to diophantine equations can be reduced to our problem. Given a diophantine equation, it is possible to construct a database Dğ·Ditalic_D and a set of ICs IC such that the existence of an LS-fix for Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC implies the existence of a solution to the equation, and viceversa. An example can be found in Appendix 0.A.2. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Proposition 2:Â First for the skeptical semantics. Given a database instance Dğ·Ditalic_D, consider the instance (D,ğ‘›ğ‘œ)ğ·ğ‘›ğ‘œ(D,{\it no})( italic_D , italic_no ) for ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´â¢(ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ‘†ğ‘˜)ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ¼ğ¶ğ‘†ğ‘˜{\it CQA}({\it False},{\textit{IC}},{\it Sk})italic_CQA ( italic_False , IC , italic_Sk ), corresponding to the question â€œIs there an LS-fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC that does not satisfy ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ¹ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’{\it False}italic_False?â€ has answer ğ‘Œğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘Œğ‘’ğ‘ {\it Yes}italic_Yes iff the class of LS-fixes of Dğ·Ditalic_D is empty. For the majority semantics, for the instance (D,ğ‘›ğ‘œ)ğ·ğ‘›ğ‘œ(D,\it{no})( italic_D , italic_no ) for ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´â¢(ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’,ğ¼ğ¶,ğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘—)ğ¶ğ‘„ğ´ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ¼ğ¶ğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘—{\it CQA}({\it True},{\textit{IC}},{\it Maj})italic_CQA ( italic_True , IC , italic_Maj ), corresponding to the question â€œIs it not the case that the majority of the LS-fixes satisfy ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’{\it True}italic_True?â€, we get answer ğ‘¦ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘’ğ‘ {\it yes}italic_yes iff the set of LS-fixes is empty. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Theorem 4.2:Â (a) First of all, we notice that a linear denial with implicit equalities, i.e. occurrences of a same variable in two different database atoms, e.g. âˆ€X,Y,ZÂ¬(R(X,Y),Q(Y,Z),\forall X,Y,Z\neg(R(X,Y),Q(Y,Z),âˆ€ italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z Â¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_Q ( italic_Y , italic_Z ) , Z>3)Z>3)italic_Z > 3 ), can be replaced by its explicit version with explicit equalities, e.g. âˆ€X,Y,Z,WÂ¬(R(X,Y),\forall X,Y,Z,W\neg(R(X,Y),âˆ€ italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z , italic_W Â¬ ( italic_R ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , Q(W,Z),Y=W,Z>3)Q(W,Z),Y=W,Z>3)italic_Q ( italic_W , italic_Z ) , italic_Y = italic_W , italic_Z > 3 ).

Let nğ‘›nitalic_n be the number of tuples in the database, and lğ‘™litalic_l be the number of attributes which participate in IC. They are those that appear in built-in predicates in the explicit versions of the ICs that do not belong to a key or are equal to a key (because they are not allowed to change). For example, given the denial Â¬â¡(Pâ¢(X,Y),Qâ¢(X,Z),Y>2)ğ‘ƒğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘„ğ‘‹ğ‘ğ‘Œ2\neg(P(X,Y),Q(X,Z),Y>2)Â¬ ( italic_P ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_Q ( italic_X , italic_Z ) , italic_Y > 2 ), since its explicit version is Â¬â¡(Pâ¢(X,Y),Qâ¢(W,Z),Y>2,X=W)ğ‘ƒğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘„ğ‘Šğ‘ğ‘Œ2ğ‘‹ğ‘Š\neg(P(X,Y),Q(W,Z),Y>2,X=W)Â¬ ( italic_P ( italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_Q ( italic_W , italic_Z ) , italic_Y > 2 , italic_X = italic_W ), the number lğ‘™litalic_l is 1 (for Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y) if Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is a key for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P or Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, and 3333 if Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is not a key (for Y,X,Wğ‘Œğ‘‹ğ‘ŠY,X,Witalic_Y , italic_X , italic_W).

If there exist an LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)â‰¤kÎ”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘˜\Delta(D,D^{\prime})\leq kroman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_k, then no value in a fixable attribute in Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT differs from its corresponding value (through the key value) in Dğ·Ditalic_D by more than kğ‘˜\sqrt{k}square-root start_ARG italic_k end_ARG. In consequence, the size of an LS-fix may not differ from the original instance by more than lÃ—nÃ—ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›â¢(k)/2ğ‘™ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘˜2l\times n\times{\it bin}(k)/2italic_l Ã— italic_n Ã— italic_bin ( italic_k ) / 2, where ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›â¢(k)ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘˜{\it bin}(k)italic_bin ( italic_k ) is the size of the binary representation of kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Thus, the size of an LS-fix is polynomially bounded by the size of Dğ·Ditalic_D and kğ‘˜kitalic_k. Since we can determine in polynomial time if Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies the ICs and if the distance is smaller than kğ‘˜kitalic_k, we obtain the result.

(b) Membership: According to Proposition 1, there is an LS-fix at a square distance â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k iff there is an instance Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the same key values that satisfies ICÂ at a square distance â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k. We use Proposition 4.2.

Hardness: We can reduce Vertex Cover (VC) to ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒâ¢(ğ¼ğ¶0)ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ¼ğ¶0{\it DFP}({\textit{IC}}_{0})italic_DFP ( IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for a fixed set of denials ğ¼ğ¶0subscriptğ¼ğ¶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Given an instance (ğ’±,â„°),ğ’±â„°(\cal{V},\cal{E}),( caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E ) , kğ‘˜kitalic_k for VC, consider a database Dğ·Ditalic_D with a relation Eâ¢(X,Y)ğ¸ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒE(X,Y)italic_E ( italic_X , italic_Y ) and key {X,Y}ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ\{X,Y\}{ italic_X , italic_Y } for the edges of the graph, and a relation for the vertices Vâ¢(X,ğ¶â„ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘›)ğ‘‰ğ‘‹ğ¶â„ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘›V(X,{\it Chosen})italic_V ( italic_X , italic_Chosen ), where Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is the key and attribute ğ¶â„ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ¶â„ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘›{\it Chosen}italic_Chosen, the only fixable attribute, is initially set to 00. The constraint ğ¼ğ¶::ğ¼ğ¶absent{\textit{IC}}:IC : âˆ€X,Y,C1,C2â¢Â¬â¡(Eâ¢(X,Y)âˆ§Vâ¢(X,C1)âˆ§Vâ¢(Y,C2)âˆ§C1<1âˆ§C2<1)for-allğ‘‹ğ‘Œsubscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2ğ¸ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘‰ğ‘‹subscriptğ¶1ğ‘‰ğ‘Œsubscriptğ¶2subscriptğ¶11subscriptğ¶21\forall X,Y,C_{1},C_{2}\neg(E(X,Y)\land V(X,C_{1})\land V(Y,C_{2})\land C_{1}<1\land C_{2}<1)âˆ€ italic_X , italic_Y , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â¬ ( italic_E ( italic_X , italic_Y ) âˆ§ italic_V ( italic_X , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ§ italic_V ( italic_Y , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ§ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 âˆ§ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 ) expresses that for any edge, at least one of the incident vertices is covered. A vertex cover of size kğ‘˜kitalic_k exists iff there exists an LS-fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC at a distance â‰¤kabsentğ‘˜\leq kâ‰¤ italic_k. The encoding is polynomial in the size of the original graph. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Theorem 4.3:Â (a) For hardness, linear denials are good enough. 4. Integrity constraints:
âˆ€iâ¢xâ¢yâ¢zâ¢Â¬â¡(ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(i,x,y,z),x<1,y<1,z<1)for-allğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¥1ğ‘¦1ğ‘§1\forall ixyz\neg({\it Vertex}(i,x,y,z),x<1,y<1,z<1)âˆ€ italic_i italic_x italic_y italic_z Â¬ ( italic_Vertex ( italic_i , italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) , italic_x < 1 , italic_y < 1 , italic_z < 1 ); âˆ€iâ¢xâ¢yâ¢zâ¢Â¬â¡(ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(i,x,y,z),x>1)for-allğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¥1\forall ixyz\neg({\it Vertex}(i,x,y,z),x>1)âˆ€ italic_i italic_x italic_y italic_z Â¬ ( italic_Vertex ( italic_i , italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) , italic_x > 1 ) (the same for y,zğ‘¦ğ‘§y,zitalic_y , italic_z); âˆ€iâ¢xâ¢yâ¢zâ¢Â¬â¡(ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(i,x,y,z),x=1,y=1,z=1)for-allğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¥1ğ‘¦1ğ‘§1\forall ixyz\neg({\it Vertex}(i,x,y,z),x=1,y=1,z=1)âˆ€ italic_i italic_x italic_y italic_z Â¬ ( italic_Vertex ( italic_i , italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) , italic_x = 1 , italic_y = 1 , italic_z = 1 ); âˆ€ixyzÂ¬(ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥(\forall ixyz\neg({\it Vertex}(âˆ€ italic_i italic_x italic_y italic_z Â¬ ( italic_Vertex ( i,x,y,z),x=1,y=1)i,x,y,z),x=1,y=1)italic_i , italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) , italic_x = 1 , italic_y = 1 ); etc.
âˆ€ijxyzÂ¬(ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥(i,x,y,z),ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥(j,x,y,z),ğ¸ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘’(i,j),ğ‘‡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿ(x,y,z)\forall ijxyz\neg({\it Vertex}(i,x,y,z),{\it Vertex}(j,x,y,z),{\it Edge}(i,j),{\it Tester}(x,y,z)âˆ€ italic_i italic_j italic_x italic_y italic_z Â¬ ( italic_Vertex ( italic_i , italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) , italic_Vertex ( italic_j , italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ) , italic_Edge ( italic_i , italic_j ) , italic_Tester ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_z ).

The graph is 3-colorable iff the database has an LS-fix wrt ğ¼ğ¶0subscriptğ¼ğ¶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The reduction is polynomial in the size of the graph. If there is an LS-fix of the generated instance, then the graph is 3-colorable. If the graph is colorable, then there is a consistent instance with the same key values as the original instance; then, by Proposition 1, there is an LS-fix.

For membership, it suffices to prove that if an LS-fix exists, then its square distance to Dğ·Ditalic_D is polynomially bounded by the size of Dğ·Ditalic_D, considering both the number of tuples and the values taken by the fixable attributes.

We will show that if an LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT exists, then all the values in its fixable attributes are bounded above by the maximum of n1+n+1subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘›1n_{1}+n+1italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n + 1 and n2+n+1subscriptğ‘›2ğ‘›1n_{2}+n+1italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_n + 1, where nğ‘›nitalic_n is the number of tuples in the database, n1subscriptğ‘›1n_{1}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the maximum absolute value in a fixable attribute in Dğ·Ditalic_D, and n2subscriptğ‘›2n_{2}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the maximum absolute value of a constant appearing in the ICs.

The set of denial ICs put in disjunctive form gives us a representation for all the ways we have to restore the consistency of the database. So, we have a constraint of the formÂ  Ï†1âˆ§Ï†2â¢â‹¯â¢Ï†msubscriptğœ‘1subscriptğœ‘2â‹¯subscriptğœ‘ğ‘š\varphi_{1}\land\varphi_{2}\cdots\varphi_{m}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ§ italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where each Ï†isubscriptğœ‘ğ‘–\varphi_{i}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a disjunction of negated database atoms and inequalities, e.g. something like Â¬â¢Pâ¢(X,Y,Z)âˆ¨Â¬â¢Râ¢(X1,Y1)âˆ¨Xâ‰¤c1âˆ¨Yâ‰¤c2âˆ¨Zâ‰ Y1ğ‘ƒğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘…subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œ1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘1ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œ1\neg P(X,Y,Z)\lor\neg R(X_{1},Y_{1})\lor X\leq c_{1}\lor Y\leq c_{2}\lor Z\neq Y_{1}Â¬ italic_P ( italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z ) âˆ¨ Â¬ italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¨ italic_X â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_Y â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_Z â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since fixes can be obtained by changing values of non key attributes, each tuple in a fix is determined by a set of constraints, each of which is a disjunction of atoms of the form Xiâ¢Î¸iâ¢cmsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘šX_{i}\theta_{i}c_{m}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or Xiâ‰ Yjsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘—X_{i}\neq Y_{j}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i}italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an inequality of the form â‰¤,â‰¥,<,>\leq,\geq,<,>â‰¤ , â‰¥ , < , >. E.g. from Â¬â¢Pâ¢(X,Y,Z)âˆ¨Â¬â¢Râ¢(X1,Y1)âˆ¨Xâ‰¤c1âˆ¨Yâ‰¤c2âˆ¨Zâ‰ Y1ğ‘ƒğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘…subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘Œ1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘1ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œ1\neg P(X,Y,Z)\lor\neg R(X_{1},Y_{1})\lor X\leq c_{1}\lor Y\leq c_{2}\lor Z\neq Y_{1}Â¬ italic_P ( italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Z ) âˆ¨ Â¬ italic_R ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¨ italic_X â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_Y â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_Z â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we get Xâ‰¤c1âˆ¨Yâ‰¤c2âˆ¨Zâ‰ Y1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘1ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œ1X\leq c_{1}\lor Y\leq c_{2}\lor Z\neq Y_{1}italic_X â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_Y â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_Z â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which for a specific tuple becomes Yâ‰¤c2âˆ¨Zâ‰ Y1ğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘2ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œ1Y\leq c_{2}\lor Z\neq Y_{1}italic_Y â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_Z â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is part of the key and its specific value for the tuple at hand does not satisfy Xâ‰¤c1ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘1X\leq c_{1}italic_X â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (otherwise we drop the constraint for that tuple). In any case, every tuple in a fix can take values in a space Sğ‘†Sitalic_S that is the intersection of the half-spaces defined by inequalities of the form Xiâ¢Î¸iâ¢cmsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘šX_{i}\theta_{i}c_{m}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT minus the set of points determined by the non-equalities Xiâ‰ Yjsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘—X_{i}\neq Y_{j}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

If there is a set of values that satisfies the resulting constraints, i.e. if there is an instance with the same key values that satisfies the ICs, then we can find an LS-fix at the right distance: if the difference between any value and mâ¢aâ¢xâ¢(c1,â‹¯,cl)ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘™max(c_{1},\cdots,c_{l})italic_m italic_a italic_x ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is more than n+1ğ‘›1n+1italic_n + 1 (the most we need to be sure the inequalities Xiâ‰ Yjsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘—X_{i}\neq Y_{j}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are satisfied), then we systematically change values by 1, making them closer to the borders of the half-spaces, but still keeping the points within Sğ‘†Sitalic_S.

(b) ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it coNP}italic_coNP-hardness follows from Proposition 2 and part (a). â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Theorem 4.4:Â (a) We reduce 3-SATâ€™s complement to LS-fix checking for a fixed schema and set of denials IC. We have a table ğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘¡â¢(l,lÂ¯)ğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘™Â¯ğ‘™{\it Lit}(l,\bar{l})italic_Lit ( italic_l , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_l end_ARG ) storing complementary literals (only), e.g. (p,Â¬â¢p)ğ‘ğ‘(p,\neg p)( italic_p , Â¬ italic_p ) if pğ‘pitalic_p is one of the variables in the instance for SAT. Also a table ğ¶ğ‘™ğ¶ğ‘™{\it Cl}italic_Cl storing tuples of the form (Ï†,l,k)ğœ‘ğ‘™ğ‘˜(\varphi,l,k)( italic_Ï† , italic_l , italic_k ), where Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† is a clause (we assume all the clauses have exactly 3 literals, which can be simulated by adding extra literals with unchangeable value 00 if necessary), lğ‘™litalic_l is a literal in the clause, and kğ‘˜kitalic_k takes value 00 or 1111 (the truth value of lğ‘™litalic_l in Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï†). The first two arguments are the key of Cğ¶Citalic_C. Finally, we have a table ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥â¢(K,N)ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ¾ğ‘{\it Aux}(K,N)italic_Aux ( italic_K , italic_N ), with key Kğ¾Kitalic_K and fixable numerical attribute Nğ‘Nitalic_N, and a table ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šâ¢(N)ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘{\it Num}(N)italic_Num ( italic_N ) with a rigid numerical attribute Nğ‘Nitalic_N.

Given an instance Î¦=Ï†1âˆ§â‹¯âˆ§Ï†mÎ¦subscriptğœ‘1â‹¯subscriptğœ‘ğ‘š\Phi=\varphi_{1}\wedge\cdots\wedge\varphi_{m}roman_Î¦ = italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ§ â‹¯ âˆ§ italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for 3-SAT, we produce an initial extension Dğ·Ditalic_D for the relations in the obvious manner, assigning arbitrary truth values to the literals, but making sure that the same literal takes the same truth value in every clause, and complementary literals take complementary truth values. ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥{\it Aux}italic_Aux contains (0,0)00(0,0)( 0 , 0 ) as its only tuple; and ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘š{\it Num}italic_Num contains (s+1)ğ‘ 1(s+1)( italic_s + 1 ), where sğ‘ sitalic_s is the number of different propositional variables in Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦.

Consider now the following set of denials:
(a) Â¬â¡(ğ¶ğ‘™â¢(Ï†,L,U),U>1)ğ¶ğ‘™ğœ‘ğ¿ğ‘ˆğ‘ˆ1\neg({\it Cl}(\varphi,L,U),U>1)Â¬ ( italic_Cl ( italic_Ï† , italic_L , italic_U ) , italic_U > 1 ); Â¬â¡(ğ¶ğ‘™â¢(Ï†,L,U),U<0)ğ¶ğ‘™ğœ‘ğ¿ğ‘ˆğ‘ˆ0\neg({\it Cl}(\varphi,L,U),U<~{}0)Â¬ ( italic_Cl ( italic_Ï† , italic_L , italic_U ) , italic_U < 0 ) Â Â (possible truth values).
(b) Â¬(ğ¶ğ‘™(Ï†,L,U),\neg({\it Cl}(\varphi,L,U),Â¬ ( italic_Cl ( italic_Ï† , italic_L , italic_U ) , ğ¶ğ‘™(Ïˆ,L,{\it Cl}(\psi,L,italic_Cl ( italic_Ïˆ , italic_L , V),V),italic_V ) , Uâ‰ V)U\neq V)italic_U â‰  italic_V ) Â Â (same value for a literal everywhere).
(c) Â¬(ğ¶ğ‘™(Ï†,L,U),\neg({\it Cl}(\varphi,L,U),Â¬ ( italic_Cl ( italic_Ï† , italic_L , italic_U ) , ğ¶ğ‘™(Ïˆ,Lâ€²,V),ğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘¡(L,Lâ€²),U=V){\it Cl}(\psi,L^{\prime},V),{\it Lit}(L,L^{\prime}),U=V)italic_Cl ( italic_Ïˆ , italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_V ) , italic_Lit ( italic_L , italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_U = italic_V ) Â Â (complementary literals).
(d) Â¬(ğ¶ğ‘™(Ï†,L,U),ğ¶ğ‘™(Ï†,Lâ€²,V),ğ¶ğ‘™(Ï†,Lâ€²â€²,W),U=V=W=0,Lâ‰ Lâ€²,â€¦,\neg({\it Cl}(\varphi,L,U),{\it Cl}(\varphi,L^{\prime},V),{\it Cl}(\varphi,L^{\prime\prime},W),U=V=W=0,L\neq L^{\prime},...,Â¬ ( italic_Cl ( italic_Ï† , italic_L , italic_U ) , italic_Cl ( italic_Ï† , italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_V ) , italic_Cl ( italic_Ï† , italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_W ) , italic_U = italic_V = italic_W = 0 , italic_L â‰  italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥(K,N),N=0){\it Aux}(K,N),N=0)italic_Aux ( italic_K , italic_N ) , italic_N = 0 ) (each clause becomes true).
(e) Â¬â¡(ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šâ¢(Z),ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥â¢(K,N),Nâ‰ 0,Nâ‰ Z)ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘0ğ‘ğ‘\neg({\it Num}(Z),{\it Aux}(K,N),N\neq 0,N\neq Z)Â¬ ( italic_Num ( italic_Z ) , italic_Aux ( italic_K , italic_N ) , italic_N â‰  0 , italic_N â‰  italic_Z ) Â Â (possible values).

It holds that the formula is unsatisfiable iff the instance Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that coincides with Dğ·Ditalic_D except for ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¥{\it Aux}italic_Aux that now has the only tuple (0,s+1)0ğ‘ 1(0,s+1)( 0 , italic_s + 1 ) is an LS-fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC. Thus, checking Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for LS-fix is enough to check unsatisfiability.

For membership to ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it coNP}italic_coNP, for an initial instance Dğ·Ditalic_D, instances Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the complement of ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥â¢(ğ¼ğ¶)ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ¼ğ¶{\it Fix}({\textit{IC}})italic_Fix ( IC ) have witnesses Dâ€²â€²superscriptğ·â€²â€²D^{\prime\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that can be checked in polynomial time, namely instances Dâ€²â€²superscriptğ·â€²â€²D^{\prime\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that have the same key values as Dğ·Ditalic_D, satisfy the ICs, but Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²â€²)<Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²â€²Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²\Delta(D,D^{\prime\prime})<\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

(b) For the first claim on CQA, let IC and a query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q be given. The complement of CQA is in ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}^{{\it coNP}}italic_NP start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_coNP end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: Given an instance Dğ·Ditalic_D, non deterministically choose an instance Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Dâ€²âŠ§Ì¸Qnot-modelssuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘„D^{\prime}\not\models Qitalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§Ì¸ italic_Q and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D. The latter test can be done in ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it coNP}italic_coNP (by part (a)). But ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒ=Nâ¢PÎ£1P=Î£2Psuperscriptğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘superscriptğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptÎ£1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptÎ£2ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}^{{\it coNP}}=NP^{\Sigma_{1}^{P}}=\Sigma_{2}^{P}italic_NP start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_coNP end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_N italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In consequence, CQA belongs to ğ‘ğ‘œâ¢Î£2P=Î 2Pğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptÎ£2ğ‘ƒsubscriptsuperscriptÎ ğ‘ƒ2{\it co}\Sigma_{2}^{P}=\Pi^{P}_{2}italic_co roman_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Î  start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

For the second claim, we prove hardness of CQA by a ğ¿ğ‘‚ğºğ‘†ğ‘ƒğ´ğ¶ğ¸ğ¿ğ‘‚ğºğ‘†ğ‘ƒğ´ğ¶ğ¸{\it LOGSPACE}italic_LOGSPACE-reduction from the following problem [17, Theo. 3.4]: Given a Boolean formula Ïˆâ¢(X1,â‹¯,Xn)ğœ“subscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›\psi(X_{1},\cdots,X_{n})italic_Ïˆ ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in 3CNF, decide if the last variable Xnsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X_{n}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is equal to 1111 in the lexicographically maximum satisfying assignment (the answer is false if Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ is not satisfiable).

Given the clauses C1,â€¦,Cmsubscriptğ¶1â€¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘šC_{1},\ldots,C_{m}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ, we create a database Dğ·Ditalic_D with relations ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿâ¢(ğ‘–ğ‘‘,ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ,ğ‘“ğ‘,ğ‘¤ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡),ğ¶ğ‘™â¢(ğ‘–ğ‘‘,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™1,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ2,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™2,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ3,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™3)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘¤ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ2subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™2subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ3subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™3{\it Var(id,tr,fa,weight)},{\it Cl(id,var_{1},val_{1},var_{2},val_{2},var_{3},val_{3})}italic_Var ( italic_id , italic_tr , italic_fa , italic_weight ) , italic_Cl ( italic_id , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and constraints:

  1. 1.

    âˆ€iâ¢d,tâ¢r,fâ¢aâ¢Â¬â¡(Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(iâ¢d,tâ¢r,fâ¢a,_)âˆ§tâ¢râ‰¤0âˆ§fâ¢aâ‰¤0)for-allğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘“ğ‘_ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ0ğ‘“ğ‘0\forall id,tr,fa\neg(Var(id,tr,fa,\_)\land tr\leq 0\land fa\leq 0)âˆ€ italic_i italic_d , italic_t italic_r , italic_f italic_a Â¬ ( italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_i italic_d , italic_t italic_r , italic_f italic_a , _ ) âˆ§ italic_t italic_r â‰¤ 0 âˆ§ italic_f italic_a â‰¤ 0 )

    âˆ€id,v1,x1,v2,x2,v3,x3Â¬(Cl(id,v1,x1,v2,x2,v3,x3)âˆ§Var(_,v1,x1â€²)âˆ§Var(_,v2,x2â€²)\forall id,v_{1},x_{1},v_{2},x_{2},v_{3},x_{3}\neg(Cl(id,v_{1},x_{1},v_{2},x_{2},v_{3},x_{3})\land The extended denial constraint in 4. could be replaced by eight non-extended denial constraints.

For each variable Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, insert a tuple (Xi,0,0,2nâˆ’i)subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–00superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘–(X_{i},0,0,2^{n-i})( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 , 0 , 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) into ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ{\it Var}italic_Var. It is easy to see that all the fixes Dğ·Ditalic_D represent satisfying assignments for Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ, such that in case a tuple (Xi,1,0,_)subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–10_(X_{i},1,0,\_)( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 , 0 , _ ) is in a fix, then value ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’{\it true}italic_true must be assigned to variable Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; and value ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ ğ‘’{\it false}italic_false must be assigned to Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in case (Xi,0,1,_)subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–01_(X_{i},0,1,\_)( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 , 1 , _ ) is in the fix. If Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ is unsatisfiable, then there are no fixes.

Let us now consider the cost of a repair. Assume that S1=xi11,â€¦,xim11subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–11â€¦subscriptğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘š1S_{1}=x_{i^{1}_{1}},\ldots,x_{i^{1}_{m_{1}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S2=xi12,â€¦,xim22subscriptğ‘†2subscriptğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–21â€¦subscriptğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–2subscriptğ‘š2S_{2}=x_{i^{2}_{1}},\ldots,x_{i^{2}_{m_{2}}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are satisfying assignments with S1â‰ºS2precedessubscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{1}\prec S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT under lexicographical order. The cost of repair Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is equal to 2nâˆ’i1+2ni2+â‹¯+2nimX+nsuperscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–1superscript2subscriptğ‘›subscriptğ‘–2â‹¯superscript2subscriptğ‘›subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘šğ‘‹ğ‘›2^{n-{i_{1}}}+2^{n_{i_{2}}}+\cdots+2^{n_{i_{m_{X}}}}+n2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + â‹¯ + 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n, because (a) we have to update attribute ğ‘¤ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡ğ‘¤ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡{\it weight}italic_weight for each variable that is assigned value ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’{\it true}italic_true, and (b) for each tuple in relation ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ{\it Var}italic_Var, attribute ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ{\it tr}italic_tr or attribute ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘{\it fa}italic_fa is changed by 1111.

Because of (a), there exists a term 2nâˆ’im1superscript2ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ‘–1ğ‘š2^{n-i^{1}_{m}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the cost of S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is bigger than the sum of all terms in S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with index â‰¥im2absentsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘–2ğ‘š\geq i^{2}_{m}â‰¥ italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So, the cost of the fix representing S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is greater than the cost of the fix representing S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In consequence, the minimal fix would be the maximum according to the lexicographical order of satisfying assignments.

The answer to the ground atomic query ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿâ¢(Xn,1,0,1)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›101{\it Var}(X_{n},1,0,1)italic_Var ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 , 0 , 1 ) is true iff Xnsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›X_{n}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT takes the value 1111 in the l.o. greatest assignment. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Theorem 4.5:Â The reduction can be established with a fixed set ğ¼ğ¶0subscriptğ¼ğ¶0{\textit{IC}}_{0}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ICs. In the previous proof, the first two ICs in ğ¼ğ¶0subscriptğ¼ğ¶0{\it IC}_{0}italic_IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be eliminated, and the third one is local (c.f. Definition 5). In consequence, the theorem also holds for local denials.

Proof of Proposition 3:Â By reduction from the ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ´ğ‘‹ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it MAXSNP}italic_MAXSNP-hard problem B-Minimum Vertex Cover (BMVC), which asks to find a minimum vertex cover in a graph whose nodes have a bounded degree [16, chap. 10]. This gives us an Lğ¿Litalic_L-reduction from BMVC to ğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘ƒ{\it DFP}italic_DFP [21]. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Lemma A.3. Proof:Â Tuple tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can only differ from tğ‘¡titalic_t in the value of fixable attributes. Since tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a local fix, Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is not empty and there is a set ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of constraints for which tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT solves the inconsistency in which tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT was involved. There is an interval [cl,+âˆ)subscriptğ‘ğ‘™[c_{l},+\infty)[ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , + âˆ ) for Ağ´Aitalic_A that can be obtained by the limits given in ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that show the values of Ağ´Aitalic_A that would force the satisfaction of the constraints in ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that have attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A in an inequality.     • â€“

      Let us consider first that Iâˆ‰â„â¢(D,iâ¢c,t)ğ¼â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡I\not\in{\cal I}(D,ic,t)italic_I âˆ‰ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_i italic_c , italic_t ). We have that Iâˆˆâ‹ƒlâˆˆDâ€²â„(Dâ€²,I\in\bigcup_{l\in D^{\prime}}{\cal I}(D^{\prime},italic_I âˆˆ â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ğ‘–ğ‘,l){\it ic},l)italic_ic , italic_l ) and since tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the only difference between Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have Iâˆˆâ„â¢(Dâ€²,ğ‘–ğ‘,tâ€²)ğ¼â„superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘–ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡â€²I\in{\cal I}(D^{\prime},{\it ic},t^{\prime})italic_I âˆˆ caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ic , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Since all the constraints can only have attribute Ağ´Aitalic_A with >>> or â‰¥\geqâ‰¥ we now that in particular ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic does. Since Iâˆ‰â„â¢(D,iâ¢c,t)ğ¼â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡I\not\in{\cal I}(D,ic,t)italic_I âˆ‰ caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_i italic_c , italic_t ) we know that Ağ´Aitalic_A satisfied the condition in ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘{\it ic}italic_ic and since we know that tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a bigger value than in tğ‘¡titalic_t, it is not possible to generate an inconsistency in Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We have reached a contradiction.

    • â€“

      Let us consider ((Iâˆ–{t})âˆª{tâ€²})âŠ§Ì¸iâ¢cnot-modelsğ¼ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘–ğ‘((I\smallsetminus\{t\})\cup\{t^{\prime}\})\not\models ic( ( italic_I âˆ– { italic_t } ) âˆª { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) âŠ§Ì¸ italic_i italic_c. Then Iâˆˆâ„â¢(Dâ€²,iâ¢c,tâ€²)ğ¼â„superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘–ğ‘superscriptğ‘¡â€²I\in{\cal I}(D^{\prime},ic,t^{\prime})italic_I âˆˆ caligraphic_I ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_i italic_c , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). From our assumption Iâˆ‰â‹ƒlâˆˆDâ„â¢(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,l)ğ¼subscriptğ‘™ğ·â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘™I\not\in\bigcup_{l\in D}{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},l)italic_I âˆ‰ â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l âˆˆ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_l ).This is the same situation analyzed in previous item.

In all the cases we have reached contradiction and therefore the proposition is proved. Since we never used the property of minimal distance between tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tğ‘¡titalic_t, the second part of the Lemma is also proved. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡


Proposition A.2. For local denials it always exists an LS-fix for a database Dğ·Ditalic_D; and for every LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Dâ€²âˆ–Dsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ·D^{\prime}\smallsetminus Ditalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– italic_D is a set of local fixes. Furthermore, for each violation set (I,ğ‘–ğ‘)ğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘(I,{\it ic})( italic_I , italic_ic ), there is a tuple tâˆˆIğ‘¡ğ¼t\in Iitalic_t âˆˆ italic_I and a local fix tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for tğ‘¡titalic_t, such that (I,ğ‘–ğ‘)âˆˆSâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²(I,{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})( italic_I , italic_ic ) âˆˆ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof:Â  Since each attribute A can only be associated to <<< or >>> built-ins, but not both, it is clear that set of local denials is always consistent. By Lemma A.0.A.1, there always exists an LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now we need to prove that Dâ€²âˆ–Dsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ·D^{\prime}\smallsetminus Ditalic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– italic_D is a set of local fixes. By contradiction assume that tâ€²âˆˆ(Dâ€²âˆ–D)superscriptğ‘¡â€²superscriptğ·â€²ğ·t^{\prime}\in(D^{\prime}\smallsetminus D)italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– italic_D ) is not a local fix of the tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t. This can happen in the following situations:

  • â€¢

    tğ‘¡titalic_t was consistent. From Lemma A.0.A.1 we know that no new inconsistencies can be added by the modifications done to the other tuples and therefore tğ‘¡titalic_t is not related to any inconsistency. Then Dâ‹†=Dâ€²âˆ–{tâ€²}âˆª{t}superscriptğ·â‹†superscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘¡D^{\star}=D^{\prime}\smallsetminus\{t^{\prime}\}\cup\{t\}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } âˆª { italic_t } is also consistent and Î”â¢(D,Dâ‹†)<Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â‹†Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²\Delta(D,D^{\star})<\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). But Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix so this is not possible.

  • â€¢

    tğ‘¡titalic_t is involved at least in one violation set. If Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)=âˆ…ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime})=\emptysetitalic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ… then tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not solving any violation set and therefore Dâ‹†=Dâ€²âˆ–{tâ€²}âˆª{t}superscriptğ·â‹†superscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘¡D^{\star}=D^{\prime}\smallsetminus\{t^{\prime}\}\cup\{t\}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ– { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } âˆª { italic_t } is also consistent and Î”â¢(D,Dâ‹†)<Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â‹†Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²\Delta(D,D^{\star})<\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). But Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix so this is not possible. Now, if Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)â‰ âˆ…ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime})\neq\emptysetitalic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰  âˆ…, from Lemma A.0.A.1, considering D={t}ğ·ğ‘¡D=\{t\}italic_D = { italic_t } and ğ¼ğ¶={ğ‘–ğ‘|(I,ğ‘–ğ‘)âˆˆSâ¢(t,tâ€²)}ğ¼ğ¶conditional-setğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²{\textit{IC}}=\{{\it ic}|(I,{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})\}IC = { italic_ic | ( italic_I , italic_ic ) âˆˆ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) }, there exists an LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Dğ·Ditalic_D, i.e. there exists a local fix tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that Sâ¢(t,tâ€²â€²)=Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²S(t,t^{\prime\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).
