Again, this is not possible because Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an LS-fix

The second part of the proposition can be proved using Lemma A.0.A.1 and considering a database D=Iğ·ğ¼D=Iitalic_D = italic_I and a set of constraints ğ¼ğ¶={ğ‘–ğ‘}ğ¼ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘{\textit{IC}}=\{{\it ic}\}IC = { italic_ic }. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Proposition 4:Â For the first claim, membership follows from Theorem 4.2(b); and for hardness, we can do the same reduction as in Theorem 4.2(b), because the ICs used there are local denials. For the second claim, it is not difficult to see that the non-local denials in the proof of Proposition 3 can be eliminated. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡


Proposition A.3. For a database Dğ·Ditalic_D and a set of local denial constraints IC:

  1. 1.

    For a set of local fixes {t1,â€¦â¢tn}subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\{t_{1},\dots t_{n}\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of a tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t there always exists a local fix tâ‹†superscriptğ‘¡â‹†t^{\star}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that Sâ¢(t,tâ‹†)=â‹ƒi=1nSâ¢(t,ti)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘†ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–S(t,t^{\star})=\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}S(t,t_{i})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  2. 2.

    For local fixes tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of a tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t with Sâ¢(t,tâ€²â€²â€²)=Sâ¢(t,tâ€²)âˆªSâ¢(t,tâ€²â€²)ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²S(t,t^{\prime\prime\prime})=S(t,t^{\prime})\cup S(t,t^{\prime\prime})italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆª italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), it holds that Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²â€²})â‰¤Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²})+Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²})Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})\leq\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) â‰¤ roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof:Â First we prove item (1). Let ICt={ğ‘–ğ‘|â„(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,t)â‰ âˆ…IC_{t}=\{{\it ic}|{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)\neq\emptysetitalic_I italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_ic | caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) â‰  âˆ… and Iâ¢CSâ¢(t,tâ€²)={ğ‘–ğ‘|(I,ğ‘–ğ‘)âˆˆSâ¢(t,tâ€²)}ğ¼subscriptğ¶ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²conditional-setğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²IC_{S}(t,t^{\prime})=\{{\it ic}|(I,{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})\}italic_I italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = { italic_ic | ( italic_I , italic_ic ) âˆˆ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) }. From Lemma A.0.A.1, considering D={t}ğ·ğ‘¡D=\{t\}italic_D = { italic_t } and IC any subset of ğ¼ğ¶tsubscriptğ¼ğ¶ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}_{t}IC start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, there always exists an LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Dğ·Ditalic_D. This LS-fix is a local fix of tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t with Iâ¢CSâ¢(t,tâ€²)=ğ¼ğ¶ğ¼subscriptğ¶ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ¼ğ¶IC_{S}(t,t^{\prime})={\textit{IC}}italic_I italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = IC. Since we can find a local fix for any ğ¼ğ¶âŠ†Stğ¼ğ¶subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡{\textit{IC}}\subseteq S_{t}IC âŠ† italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then clearly the lemma can be satisfied.

Now we will prove item (2). If the fixable attributes that where modified in tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are disjoint, then tâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT when combining the modifications Iâ€™ll get Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²â€²})=Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²})+Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²})Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})=\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) = roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). Now, we will consider the case were tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have at least one fixable attribute, say Ağ´Aitalic_A that is modified by both local fixes. In this case tâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will have a value in Ağ´Aitalic_A that solves the inconsistencies solved by and tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This value will in fact correspond to the value of Ağ´Aitalic_A in tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and therefore we will have that Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²â€²})<Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²})+Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²})Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})<\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})+\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime}\})roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) < roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) + roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be the set of attributes that are modified both by tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and tâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can express the relation as follows: Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²â€²â€²})=âˆ‘Aâˆˆâ„±(Ï€Aâ¢(t)âˆ’Ï€Aâ¢(tâ€²â€²â€²))2Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²subscriptğ´â„±superscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ´ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‹ğ´superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²â€²2\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime\prime\prime}\})=\sum_{A\in{\cal F}}(\pi_{\!A}(t)-\pi_{\!A}(t^{\prime\prime\prime}))^{2}roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =âˆ‘Aâˆˆâ„±(Ï€Aâ¢(t)âˆ’Ï€Aâ¢(tâ€²))2absentsubscriptğ´â„±superscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ´ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‹ğ´superscriptğ‘¡â€²2=\sum_{A\in{\cal F}}(\pi_{\!A}(t)-\pi_{\!A}(t^{\prime}))^{2}= âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - Proposition A.4. Proof:Â To prove the first part, let us assume that Sâ¢(t,tâ€²),Sâ¢(t,tâ€²â€²)âˆˆğ’ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²â€²ğ’S(t,t^{\prime}),S(t,t^{\prime\prime})\in{\cal C}italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_C. Proof of Proposition 6:Â To prove it it is enough to construct this optimal cover. Proof of Proposition 7:Â We have to establish that the transformation of ğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ·ğ¹ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒ{\it DFOP}italic_DFOP into ğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ¶ğ‘ƒ{\it MWSCP}italic_MWSCP given above is an Lğ¿Litalic_L-reduction [21]. Proof of Proposition 8:Â Using the same arguments as in the proof of Proposition A.11 we have that since ğ’^^ğ’\hat{{\cal C}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG is a cover then Dâ¢(ğ’^)ğ·^ğ’D({\hat{\cal C}})italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) is a fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC. We need to prove that Î”â¢(D,Dâ¢(ğ’^))â‰¤lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢(N)Ã—Î”â¢(D,Dâ€²)Î”ğ·ğ·^ğ’ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘”ğ‘Î”ğ·superscriptğ·â€²\Delta(D,D(\hat{\cal C}))\leq log(N)\times\Delta(D,D^{\prime})roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D ( over^ start_ARG caligraphic_C end_ARG ) ) â‰¤ italic_l italic_o italic_g ( italic_N ) Ã— roman_Î” ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then,

Proof of Theorem 6.1:Â Based on the tractability results in [12], it suffices to show that the LS-fixes for a database Dğ·Ditalic_D are in one-to-one and polynomial time correspondence with the repairs using tuple deletions [3, 8] for a database Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT wrt a set of key dependencies.

Since we have 1ADs, the violation sets will have a single element, then, for an inconsistent tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t wrt a constraint ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ¶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic âˆˆ IC, it holds â„â¢(D,ğ‘–ğ‘,t)={t}â„ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡{\cal I}(D,{\it ic},t)=\{t\}caligraphic_I ( italic_D , italic_ic , italic_t ) = { italic_t }. Since all the violation sets are independent, in order to compute an LS-fix for Dğ·Ditalic_D, we have to generate independently all the local fixes tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all inconsistent tuples tğ‘¡titalic_t such that ({t},ğ‘–ğ‘)âˆˆSâ¢(t,tâ€²)ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²(\{t\},{\it ic})\in S(t,t^{\prime})( { italic_t } , italic_ic ) âˆˆ italic_S ( italic_t , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), with ğ‘–ğ‘âˆˆğ¼ğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘ğ¼ğ¶{\it ic}\in{\textit{IC}}italic_ic âˆˆ IC; and then combine them in all possible ways.

Those local fixes can be found by considering all the candidate fixes (not necessarily LS-minimal) that can obtained by combining all the possible limits for each attribute provided by the ICs (c.f. Proposition A.0.A.1); and then checking which of them satisfy IC, and finally choosing those that minimize Î”â¢({t},{tâ€²})Î”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡â€²\Delta(\{t\},\{t^{\prime}\})roman_Î” ( { italic_t } , { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ). There are at most 2|â„±|superscript2â„±2^{|{\cal F}|}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_F | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible candidate fixes, where â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F is the set of fixable attributes.

Let us now define a database Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT consisting of the consistent tuples in Dğ·Ditalic_D together with all the local fixes of the inconsistent tuples. By construction, Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT share the same keys. Since each inconsistent tuple in Dğ·Ditalic_D may have more than one local fix, Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT may become inconsistent wrt its key constraints. Each repair for Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, obtained by tuple deletions, will choose one local fix for each inconsistent tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t of Dğ·Ditalic_D, and therefore will determine an LS-fix of Dğ·Ditalic_D wrt IC. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of Proposition 9:Â  The ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP-complete ğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ¼ğ‘‡ğ¼ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ¼ğ‘‡ğ¼ğ‘‚ğ‘{\it PARTITION}italic_PARTITION problem [13] can be reduced to this case for a fixed set of 1ADs. Let a Ağ´Aitalic_A be a finite set, whose elements ağ‘aitalic_a have integer sizes sâ¢(a)ğ‘ ğ‘s(a)italic_s ( italic_a ). We need to determine if there exists a subset Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of Ağ´Aitalic_A, such that âˆ‘aâˆˆSsâ¢(a)=n:=(âˆ‘aâˆˆAsâ¢(a))/2subscriptğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘›assignsubscriptğ‘ğ´ğ‘ ğ‘2\sum_{a\in S}s(a)=n:=(\sum_{a\in A}s(a))/2âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_a ) = italic_n := ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a âˆˆ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_a ) ) / 2.

We use two tables: ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘¡â¢(ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡,ğ‘Šğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡)ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘Šğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡{\it Set(Element,Weight)}italic_Set ( italic_Element , italic_Weight ), with key {ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡,ğ‘Šğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡}ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘Šğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡{\it\{Element,Weight\}}{ italic_Element , italic_Weight }, containing the tuples (a,sâ¢(a))ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘(a,s(a))( italic_a , italic_s ( italic_a ) ) for aâˆˆAğ‘ğ´a\in Aitalic_a âˆˆ italic_A; and ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›â¢(ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡,X,Y)ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ{\it Selection(Element},X,Y)italic_Selection ( italic_Element , italic_X , italic_Y ), with key ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡{\it Element}italic_Element, fixable numerical attributes X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y (the partition of Ağ´Aitalic_A) taking values 00 or 1111 (which can be specified with 1ADs), and initially containing the tuples (a,0,0)ğ‘00(a,0,0)( italic_a , 0 , 0 ) for aâˆˆAğ‘ğ´a\in Aitalic_a âˆˆ italic_A. Finally, we have the 1AD âˆ€E,X,Yâ¢Â¬â¡(ğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›â¢(E,X,Y),X<1,Y<1)for-allğ¸ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘†ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ¸ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğ‘‹1ğ‘Œ1\forall E,X,Y\neg({\it Selection}(E,X,Y),X<1,Y<1)âˆ€ italic_E , italic_X , italic_Y Â¬ ( italic_Selection ( italic_E , italic_X , italic_Y ) , italic_X < 1 , italic_Y < 1 ).

There is a one-to-one correspondence between LS-repairs of the original database and partitions X,Yğ‘‹ğ‘ŒX,Yitalic_X , italic_Y of Ağ´Aitalic_A (collecting the elements with value 1111 in either Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X or Yğ‘ŒYitalic_Y). The query used in this proof is acyclic and belongs to the class ğ’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’subscriptğ’ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘’{\cal C}_{\!{\it Tree}}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Tree end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

For the proof of Theorem 6.2 we need some preliminaries. Let us define a function Fğ¹Fitalic_F, with domain ğ’¢Ã—Sğ’¢ğ‘†{\cal G}\times Scaligraphic_G Ã— italic_S, where ğ’¢=âŸ¨ğ’±,â„°âŸ©ğ’¢ğ’±â„°{\cal G}=\langle{\cal V},{\cal E}\ranglecaligraphic_G = âŸ¨ caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E âŸ© is a graph and Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is a subset of vertexes of graph ğ’¢ğ’¢\cal Gcaligraphic_G, and range non-negative integers. The function is defined as the summation over all the vertices vâˆˆSğ‘£ğ‘†v\in Sitalic_v âˆˆ italic_S, of cubes of the number of edges connecting vğ‘£vitalic_v to vertexes in the complement of Sğ‘†Sitalic_S.

Lemma A.4. Given a fixed regular undirected graph ğ’¢=(ğ’±,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’±â„°{\cal G}=({\cal V},{\cal E})caligraphic_G = ( caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E ) of degree 3333, the maximal value of Fâ¢(ğ’¢,S)ğ¹ğ’¢ğ‘†F({\cal G},S)italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_S ) on all possible sets SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq Vitalic_S âŠ† italic_V is (33Ã—|I|)superscript33ğ¼(3^{3}\times|I|)( 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— | italic_I | ) for Iğ¼Iitalic_I a maximal independent set. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof:Â Let us first assume that Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is an independent set, not necessarily maximal. In this case the answer to Fâ¢(ğ’¢,S)ğ¹ğ’¢ğ‘†F({\cal G},S)italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_S ) will be 33Ã—|S|superscript33ğ‘†3^{3}\times|S|3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— | italic_S |, because each element vâˆˆSğ‘£ğ‘†v\in Sitalic_v âˆˆ italic_S is connected to three vertices in ğ’±âˆ–Sğ’±ğ‘†{\cal V}\smallsetminus Scaligraphic_V âˆ– italic_S. Then, among independent sets, the maximum value for Fâ¢(ğ’¢,S)ğ¹ğ’¢ğ‘†F({\cal G},S)italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_S ) is 33Ã—msuperscript33ğ‘š3^{3}\times m3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— italic_m, where mğ‘šmitalic_m is the maximum cardinality of an independent set.

Let ğ’¢â¢[S]=ğ’¢â¢(S,â„°S)ğ’¢delimited-[]ğ‘†ğ’¢ğ‘†subscriptâ„°ğ‘†{\cal G}[S]={\cal G}(S,{\cal E}_{S})caligraphic_G [ italic_S ] = caligraphic_G ( italic_S , caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where â„°Ssubscriptâ„°ğ‘†{\cal E}_{S}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are all the edges (v,vâ€²)âˆˆâ„°ğ‘£superscriptğ‘£â€²â„°(v,v^{\prime})\in{\cal E}( italic_v , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E such that v,vâ€²âˆˆSğ‘£superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘†v,v^{\prime}\in Sitalic_v , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_S. Now, if Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is not an independent set, there exists a maximum independent set ISsubscriptğ¼ğ‘†I_{S}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ğ’¢â¢[S]ğ’¢delimited-[]ğ‘†{\cal G}[S]caligraphic_G [ italic_S ]. Every vâˆˆ(ğ’±âˆ–S)ğ‘£ğ’±ğ‘†v\in({\cal V}\smallsetminus S)italic_v âˆˆ ( caligraphic_V âˆ– italic_S ) is adjacent to at least one vertex in ISsubscriptğ¼ğ‘†I_{S}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, otherwise ISâˆª{v}subscriptğ¼ğ‘†ğ‘£I_{S}\cup\{v\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª { italic_v }, would be an independent set contained in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and with more vertices than ISsubscriptğ¼ğ‘†I_{S}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, contradicting our choice of ISsubscriptğ¼ğ‘†I_{S}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Now let us define Feâ¢xâ¢tâ¢(S,v)=(Flâ¢(S,v)+âˆ‘(v,vâ€²)âˆˆâ„°Flâ¢(S,vâ€²))subscriptğ¹ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘†ğ‘£superscriptğ¹ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘£subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘£â€²â„°superscriptğ¹ğ‘™ğ‘†superscriptğ‘£â€²F_{ext}(S,v)=(F^{l}(S,v)+\sum_{(v,v^{\prime})\in{\cal E}}F^{l}(S,v^{\prime}))italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_v ) = ( italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_v ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ). Since every edge vâ€²âˆˆ(Sâˆ–IS)superscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘†subscriptğ¼ğ‘†v^{\prime}\in(S\smallsetminus I_{S})italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ ( italic_S âˆ– italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is adjacent to ISsubscriptğ¼ğ‘†I_{S}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it is easy to see that:

Fâ¢(ğ’¢,S)â‰¤âˆ‘vâˆˆIFeâ¢xâ¢tâ¢(S,v)ğ¹ğ’¢ğ‘†subscriptğ‘£ğ¼subscriptğ¹ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘†ğ‘£F({\cal G},S)\leq\sum_{v\in I}F_{ext}(S,v)italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_S ) â‰¤ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v âˆˆ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_v ) (3)

We want to prove that Fâ¢(ğ’¢,S)â‰¤Fâ¢(ğ’¢,IS)ğ¹ğ’¢ğ‘†ğ¹ğ’¢subscriptğ¼ğ‘†F({\cal G},S)\leq F({\cal G},I_{S})italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_S ) â‰¤ italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). For vâˆˆISğ‘£subscriptğ¼ğ‘†v\in I_{S}italic_v âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S=â€²(Sâˆ–IS)S{\,{}^{\prime}}=(S\smallsetminus I_{S})italic_S start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_S âˆ– italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we have the following cases:

Proof of Theorem 6.2:Â (a) For sum:Â  By reduction from a variation of Independent Set, for graphs whose vertices have all the same degree. It remains ğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒ{\it NP}italic_NP-hard as a special case of Independence Set for Cubic Planar Graphs [14]. Given an undirected graph ğ’¢=(ğ’±,â„°)ğ’¢ğ’±â„°{\cal G}=({\cal V},{\cal E})caligraphic_G = ( caligraphic_V , caligraphic_E ) with degree 3333, and a minimum bound kğ‘˜kitalic_k for the size of the maximal independent set, we create a relation ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(V,C1,C2)ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘‰subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2{\it Vertex}(V,C_{1},C_{2})italic_Vertex ( italic_V , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where the key Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is a vertex and C1,C2subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2C_{1},C_{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are fixable and may take values 00 or 1111, but are all equal to 00 in the initial instance Dğ·Ditalic_D. This relation is subject to the denial ğ¼ğ¶:âˆ€V,C1,C2â¢Â¬â¡(ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(V,C1,C2),C1<1,C2<1):ğ¼ğ¶for-allğ‘‰subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘‰subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ¶11subscriptğ¶21{\it IC}\!:\forall V,C_{1},C_{2}\neg({\it Vertex}(V,C_{1},C_{2}),C_{1}<1,C_{2}<1)italic_IC : âˆ€ italic_V , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â¬ ( italic_Vertex ( italic_V , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 ). Dğ·Ditalic_D is inconsistent wrt this constraint and in any of its LS-fix each vertex vğ‘£vitalic_v will have associated a tuples ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(v,1,0)ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘£10{\it Vertex}(v,1,0)italic_Vertex ( italic_v , 1 , 0 ) or ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(v,0,1)ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘£01{\it Vertex}(v,0,1)italic_Vertex ( italic_v , 0 , 1 ) but not both. Let us define a second relation ğ¸ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘’â¢(V1,V2,W)ğ¸ğ‘‘ğ‘”ğ‘’subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2ğ‘Š{\it Edge}(V_{1},V_{2},W)italic_Edge ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W ), with rigid attributes only, that contains the tuples (v1,v2,1)subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£21(v_{1},v_{2},1)( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 ) for (v1,v2)âˆˆâ„°subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2â„°(v_{1},v_{2})\in{\cal E}( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E or (v2,v1)âˆˆâ„°subscriptğ‘£2subscriptğ‘£1â„°(v_{2},v_{1})\in{\cal E}( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E. Consider the ground aggregate conjunctive query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q:

The query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, computes the sum of cubes of the number of vertexes of Sâ€²superscriptğ‘†â€²S^{\prime}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT adjacent to vertices in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, i.e. it calculates the function from graph to nonnegative numbers corresponding to Fâ¢(ğ’¢,S)ğ¹ğ’¢ğ‘†F({\cal G},S)italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_S ) from Definition 12 with Qâ¢(Dâ€²)=Fâ¢(ğ’¢,S)ğ‘„superscriptğ·â€²ğ¹ğ’¢ğ‘†Q(D^{\prime})=F({\cal G},S)italic_Q ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_F ( caligraphic_G , italic_S ) for Dâ€²âˆˆFâ¢iâ¢xâ¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)superscriptğ·â€²ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶D^{\prime}\in Fix(D,{\it IC})italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_D , italic_IC ) and S={v|ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥â¢(v,1,0)âˆˆDâ€²}ğ‘†conditional-setğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘¥ğ‘£10superscriptğ·â€²S=\{v|{\it Vertex}(v,1,0)\in D^{\prime}\}italic_S = { italic_v | italic_Vertex ( italic_v , 1 , 0 ) âˆˆ italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

We are interested in the minimum and maximum value for Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q in Fâ¢iâ¢xâ¢(D,ğ¼ğ¶)ğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ·ğ¼ğ¶Fix(D,{\it IC})italic_F italic_i italic_x ( italic_D , italic_IC ), i.e. the min-max answer introduced in [4]. Since the function is nonnegative and since its value is zero for S=âˆ…ğ‘†S=\emptysetitalic_S = âˆ… and S=ğ’±ğ‘†ğ’±S={\cal V}italic_S = caligraphic_V we have that its minimum value is zero. We are only missing to find its maximum value.

From Lemma 0.A.1 we have that the answer to query Q is at most 33Ã—|I|superscript33ğ¼3^{3}\times|I|3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— | italic_I | with Iğ¼Iitalic_I a maximum independent set. In consequence, the min-max answer for Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is (0,Â  33Ã—msuperscript33ğ‘š3^{3}\times m3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— italic_m), with m the cardinality of the maximum independent set; and then there is an independent set of size at least kğ‘˜kitalic_k iff Â ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›âˆ’ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥â¢ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿâ¢ğ‘¡ğ‘œâ¢Qâ‰¥kÃ—33ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¤ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘„ğ‘˜superscript33{\it min\!\!-\!\!max~{}answer~{}to}~{}Q\geq k\times 3^{3}italic_min - italic_max italic_answer italic_to italic_Q â‰¥ italic_k Ã— 3 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

(b) For count distinct:Â  By reduction from MAXSAT. Assume that an instance for MAXSAT is given, consisting of a set Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U of propositional variables, a collection Cğ¶Citalic_C of clauses over Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U and a positive integer kğ‘˜kitalic_k. The question is whether at least kğ‘˜kitalic_k clauses can be satisfied simultaneously, which will get answer yes exactly when a question of the form ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘â‰¤(kâˆ’1)ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘˜1{\it countd}\leq(k-1)italic_countd â‰¤ ( italic_k - 1 ), with ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘{\it countd}italic_countd defined by an aggregate query over a database instance (both of them to be constructed below), gets answer no under the min-max semantics.

Define a relation ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿâ¢(u,c1,c2)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2{\it Var}(u,c_{1},c_{2})italic_Var ( italic_u , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), with (rigid) first key attribute, and the second and third fixable (the denial below and the minimality condition will make them take values 0 or 1). The initial database has a tuple (u,0,0)ğ‘¢00(u,0,0)( italic_u , 0 , 0 ) for every uâˆˆUğ‘¢ğ‘ˆu\in Uitalic_u âˆˆ italic_U. Another relation ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘ ğ‘’â¢(u,c,s)ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ {\it Clause}(u,c,s)italic_Clause ( italic_u , italic_c , italic_s ), has no fixable attributes and contains for every occurrence of variable uâˆˆUğ‘¢ğ‘ˆu\in Uitalic_u âˆˆ italic_U in a clause câˆˆCğ‘ğ¶c\in Citalic_c âˆˆ italic_C a tuple (u,c,s)ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ (u,c,s)( italic_u , italic_c , italic_s ) with sğ‘ sitalic_s an assignment for uğ‘¢uitalic_u satisfying clause cğ‘citalic_c. The IC is âˆ€u,c1,c2â¢Â¬â¡(ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿâ¢(u,c1,c2),c1<1,c2<1)for-allğ‘¢subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘11subscriptğ‘21\forall u,c_{1},c_{2}\neg({\it Var}(u,c_{1},c_{2}),c_{1}<1,c_{2}<1)âˆ€ italic_u , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â¬ ( italic_Var ( italic_u , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 ). The acyclic query is

qâ¢(ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘â¢(c))â†ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿâ¢(u,c1,c2),ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘ ğ‘’â¢(u,c,s),c1=s,formulae-sequenceâ†ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘1ğ‘ q({\it countd}(c))\leftarrow{\it Var}(u,c_{1},c_{2}),{\it Clause}(u,c,s),c_{1}=s,italic_q ( italic_countd ( italic_c ) ) â† italic_Var ( italic_u , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_Clause ( italic_u , italic_c , italic_s ) , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s ,

where ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘‘{\it countd}italic_countd denotes the â€œcount distinctâ€ aggregate function. Its answer tells us how many clauses are satisfied in a given LS-fix. The max value taken on a LS-fix, i.e. the min-max answer, will be the max number of clauses which may be satisfied for MAXSAT.

(c) For average:Â  By reduction from 3â¢Sâ¢Aâ¢T3ğ‘†ğ´ğ‘‡3SAT3 italic_S italic_A italic_T. Now, we encode clauses as tuples in a fixed relation
ğ¶ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘ ğ‘’(ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™1,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ2,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™2,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ3,{\it Clause(val,var_{1},val_{1},var_{2},val_{2},var_{3}},italic_Clause ( italic_val , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™3){\it val_{3})}italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ2,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ3subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ2subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ3{\it var_{1},var_{2},var_{3}}italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_var start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the variables in the clause (in any order), ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™1,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™2,ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™3subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™2subscriptğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘™3{\it val_{1},val_{2},val_{3}}italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_val start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT all possible combinations of truth assignments to variables (at most 8 combinations per clause). Then value of qğ‘qitalic_q is maximum in a LS-fix, taking value 1, i.e. the min-max answer to qğ‘qitalic_q is 1, iff the formula satisfiable. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

Proof of of Theorem 6.3:Â  First we reduce CQA under range semantics for aggregate queries with sum to RWAE2italic-RWAE2{\it RWAE2}italic_RWAE2, a restricted weighted version of the problem of solving algebraic equations over ğºğ¹â¢[2]ğºğ¹delimited-[]2{\it GF}[2]italic_GF [ 2 ], the field with two elements. Next, we prove that such an algebraic problem can be solved within constant approximation factor.

(A).Â  Reduction to RWAE2italic-RWAE2{\it RWAE2}italic_RWAE2. In order to define polynomial equations, we need variables. We introduce a set ğ’±ğ’±\cal Vcaligraphic_V of variables Xk,iRsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹ğ‘…ğ‘˜ğ‘–X^{R}_{k,i}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, taking values in ğºğ¹â¢[2]ğºğ¹delimited-[]2{\it GF}[2]italic_GF [ 2 ], for every tuple tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in an LS-fix corresponding to a tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t (a ground database atom in the database) with key kğ‘˜kitalic_k in a relation Rğ‘…Ritalic_R in the original database, i.e. tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT belongs to some LS-fix and tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT tğ‘¡titalic_t share the key values kğ‘˜kitalic_k. For example if the tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t is consistent or admits only one local fix (one attribute can be changed and in only one way), only one variable is introduced due to tğ‘¡titalic_t. Denote with ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”â¢(t)ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¡{\it bag}(t)italic_bag ( italic_t ) the set of variables introduced due to a same initial tuple tğ‘¡titalic_t.

Consider a conjunctive query

Qâ¢(sâ¢uâ¢mâ¢(z)):âˆ’R1â¢(xâ†’),â‹¯,Rmâ¢(xâ†’).:ğ‘„ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§subscriptğ‘…1â†’ğ‘¥â‹¯subscriptğ‘…ğ‘šâ†’ğ‘¥Q(sum(z)):-R_{1}(\vec{x}),\cdots,R_{m}(\vec{x}).italic_Q ( italic_s italic_u italic_m ( italic_z ) ) : - italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overâ†’ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) , â‹¯ , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overâ†’ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) .

Throughout the a proof Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ is the body of the query as a conjunction of atoms, mğ‘šmitalic_m is the number of database predicates in Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ, nğ‘›nitalic_n is the number of tuples in the database, kğ‘˜kitalic_k is the maximal number of attribute comparisons in the ICs (and the maximal number of fixes of a given tuple).

We may consider all the possible assignments Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² from database atoms in the query to grounds tuples in fixes that satisfy Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ. The number of assignments is polynomial in the size of the database, actually â‰¤nmabsentsuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘š\leq n^{m}â‰¤ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Notice that the the number of LS-fixes of a database may be exponential, but the number of local fixes of each original tuple is restricted by the number of attributes of the tuple. So, the number of all possible LS-fixes of tuples is polynomial in the size of the original database (even linear). Here we are using the fact that we have 1ADs.

Now we build a system â„°â„°\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E of weighted algebraic equations. Each such assignment Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is associated with a combination of tuples tk1,i1R1,â‹¯,tkm,imRmsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…1subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘–1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘št^{R_{1}}_{k_{1},i_{1}},\cdots,t^{R_{m}}_{k_{m},i_{m}}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ. For each combination put the following equation EÎ²superscriptğ¸ğ›½E^{\beta}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over ğºğ¹â¢[2]ğºğ¹delimited-[]2{\it GF}[2]italic_GF [ 2 ] into â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_E:

Xk1,i1R1â‹…â‹¯â¢Xkm,imRmâsâ¢eâ¢lâ¢eâ¢câ¢tâ¢eâ¢dâ‹…âˆiâ‰ i1(1âˆ’Xk1,iR1)â‹…â‹¯â‹…âˆiâ‰ im(1âˆ’Xkm,iRm)âŸnâ¢oâ¢nâˆ’sâ¢eâ¢lâ¢eâ¢câ¢tâ¢eâ¢d=1.â‹…superscriptââ‹…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘…1subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘–1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘…ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘‘subscriptâŸsubscriptproductğ‘–subscriptğ‘–1â‹…1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘…1subscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘–â‹¯subscriptproductğ‘–subscriptğ‘–ğ‘š1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹subscriptğ‘…ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘‘1\overbrace{X^{R_{1}}_{k_{1},i_{1}}\cdot\cdots X^{R_{m}}_{k_{m},i_{m}}}^{selected}\cdot\underbrace{\prod_{i\not=i_{1}}(1-X^{R_{1}}_{k_{1},i})\cdot\cdots\cdot\prod_{i\not=i_{m}}(1-X^{R_{m}}_{k_{m},i})}_{non-selected}~{}=~{}1.overâ start_ARG italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… â‹¯ italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_e italic_l italic_e italic_c italic_t italic_e italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… underâŸ start_ARG âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i â‰  italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‹… â‹¯ â‹… âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i â‰  italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_o italic_n - italic_s italic_e italic_l italic_e italic_c italic_t italic_e italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 . (4)

The first product in (4), before the first âˆproduct\prodâˆ, contains the variables corresponding to the tuples selected by Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². The rest of the product contains variables for the those tuples that were not selected, i.e. if t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT appears in the first product, with t1âˆˆbâ¢aâ¢gâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¡t_{1}\in bag(t)italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_b italic_a italic_g ( italic_t ), and t2âˆˆbâ¢aâ¢gâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¡2ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¡t_{2}\in bag(t)italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_b italic_a italic_g ( italic_t ), with t1â‰ t2subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2t_{1}\neq t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then the variable X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponding to t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT appears as (1âˆ’X2)1subscriptğ‘‹2(1-X_{2})( 1 - italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in the second part of the product. This captures the restriction that no two different tuples from the same bag can be used (because the share the key values). For each combination Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² of tuples in LS-fixes there is no more then one equation, which in turn has a polynomial number of factors.

Equation (4) gets weight wâ¢(EÎ²)ğ‘¤superscriptğ¸ğ›½w(E^{\beta})italic_w ( italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) that is equal to the value of aggregation attribute zğ‘§zitalic_z in Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î².

In this way we have an instance of the RWAE2italic-RWAE2{\it RWAE2}italic_RWAE2. It requires to find the maximum weight for a subsystem of â„°â„°\cal Ecaligraphic_E that can be (simultaneously) satisfied in ğºğ¹â¢[2]ğºğ¹delimited-[]2{\it GF}[2]italic_GF [ 2 ], where the weight of the subsystem is the sum of the weights of the individual equations. Of course, this problem also has a version as a decision problem, so as CQA under range semantics.

Claim:Â  The maximal weight of a satisfied subsystem of â„°â„°\cal Ecaligraphic_E is the same as the maximal value of Qâ¢(ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šâ¢z)ğ‘„ğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘§Q({\it sum}{z})italic_Q ( italic_sum italic_z ) over all possible LS-fixes of Dğ·Ditalic_D.

(â‰¥\geqâ‰¥)Â  Assume that query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q takes a maximum value over all possible LS-fixes of Dğ·Ditalic_D on an LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Under 1ADs a database LS-fix Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a set union of local fixes, with one local fix selected for every original tuple. Consider an assignment Ağ´Aitalic_A defined on ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V that maps variables corresponding a selected local fix to 1111 and all other variables to 00.

Consider all sets of local fixes which simultaneously satisfy Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ. If local fixes t1,â‹¯,tmsubscriptğ‘¡1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘št_{1},\cdots,t_{m}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfy Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ, then there exist exactly one equation eğ‘’eitalic_e for that given set of local fixes. The equation eğ‘’eitalic_e will be satisfied since variables corresponding to selected local fixes have value 1111, and â€œnon-selectedâ€ variables have value 00. So, for every set of local fixes satisfying the query body, there would be a satisfied equation with weight equal to the value of aggregated attribute. It means, that a solution to the algebraic equation problem is bigger or equal to the maximal query answer (min-max answer).

(â‰¤\leqâ‰¤)Â  Consider an assignment Ağ´Aitalic_A which is a solution of algebraic equation problem. It maps elements of ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V to {0,1}01\{0,1\}{ 0 , 1 } in such a way that the weight of satisfied equations of â„°â„°\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E is maximum over all possible assignment for ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V.

First we prove that if there exists a bag BğµBitalic_B such that more then one of its variables is mapped to 1111, then there exist an assignment Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the same weight of satisfied equations of â„°â„°\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E as Ağ´Aitalic_A, but BğµBitalic_B contains no more then one variable mapped to 1111.

Assume that for a bag BğµBitalic_B more then two variables (let us say Xi,Xjsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—X_{i},X_{j}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) are mapped to 1111. It means that every equation which contains variables from BğµBitalic_B will be unsatisfied, since it contains either (1âˆ’Xi)1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–(1-X_{i})( 1 - italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) or (1âˆ’Xj)1subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—(1-X_{j})( 1 - italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as factors in the equation. If we change a value of one of the variables (say Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) to 00, then no satisfied equation become unsatisfied, since satisfied equations do not contain Xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. No unsatisfied equation becomes satisfied, because due to the assumption of maximality of the weight of the satisfied subset of Eğ¸Eitalic_E for Ağ´Aitalic_A.

In a second step, we prove that if Ağ´Aitalic_A is a maximal assignment and there exist a bag BğµBitalic_B such that all of its variables are mapped to 00, then there exist an assignment Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which satisfies the same subset of â„°â„°\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E as Ağ´Aitalic_A, but at least one variable from that BğµBitalic_B is mapped to 1111.

If all variables from a bag BğµBitalic_B are mapped to 00, then all equations which contain variables from BğµBitalic_B are unsatisfied. If we change a value of one variable to 1111, then no satisfied equation becomes unsatisfied since all satisfied equations do not contain variables from BğµBitalic_B. No unsatisfied equation becomes satisfied due to maximality assumption of the weight of satisfied equation for Ağ´Aitalic_A. Taking step by step all bags from ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V, for given a maximum assignment Ağ´Aitalic_A, we produce an assignment Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which has exactly one variable from each bag mapped to 1.

Now, construct a database Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which is a set of local fixes corresponding to variables mapped to 1111. It is obviously a LS-fix, and wâ¢(Eâ¢(A))â‰¤Qâ¢(Dâ€²)ğ‘¤ğ¸ğ´ğ‘„superscriptğ·â€²w(E(A))\leq Q(D^{\prime})italic_w ( italic_E ( italic_A ) ) â‰¤ italic_Q ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

(B).Â  A deterministic approximation algorithm for RWAE2italic-RWAE2{\it RWAE2}italic_RWAE2. Â The construction and approximation factor obtained are similar those in the approximation of MAXSAT. C.f. [24, 21]. In two steps, first a randomized algorithm is produced, that is next de-randomized.

(B1).Â  Randomized approximation algorithm.Â  Assume that from each bag we select one variable with probability 1/k1ğ‘˜1/k1 / italic_k, where kğ‘˜kitalic_k is the number of variables in the bag. We map selected variable to 1111 and all other variables in the bag to 00. For each equation eğ‘’eitalic_e, random variable Wesubscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W_{e}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the weight contributed by eğ‘’eitalic_e to the total weight Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. Thus, W=âˆ‘eâˆˆâ„°Weğ‘Šsubscriptğ‘’â„°subscriptğ‘Šğ‘’W=\sum_{e\in\mathcal{E}}W_{e}italic_W = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e âˆˆ caligraphic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ„â¢[We]=weâ‹…ğğ«â¢[eÂ isÂ satisfied]ğ„delimited-[]subscriptğ‘Šğ‘’â‹…subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘’ğğ«delimited-[]eÂ isÂ satisfied\mathbf{E}[W_{e}]=w_{e}\cdot\mathbf{Pr}[\textit{e\ is\ satisfied}]bold_E [ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… bold_Pr [ e is satisfied ], where ğ„ğ„\mathbf{E}bold_E is a mathematical expectation and ğğ«ğğ«\mathbf{Pr}bold_Pr is a probability.

If the query contains mğ‘šmitalic_m predicates, then each equation contains no more than mğ‘šmitalic_m variables from different bags (never two different variables from the same bag), then ğ„â¢(We)â‰¥kâˆ’mâ¢weğ„subscriptğ‘Šğ‘’superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘’\mathbf{E}(W_{e})\geq k^{-m}w_{e}bold_E ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Now, by linearity of expectation,

ğ„â¢[W]=âˆ‘eâˆˆâ„°ğ„â¢[We]â‰¥kâˆ’mâ¢âˆ‘eâˆˆâ„°weâ‰¥kâˆ’mâ‹…Oâ¢Pâ¢T.ğ„delimited-[]ğ‘Šsubscriptğ‘’â„°ğ„delimited-[]subscriptğ‘Šğ‘’superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘’â„°subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘’â‹…superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ‘‡\mathbf{E}[W]=\sum_{e\in\mathcal{E}}\mathbf{E}[W_{e}]\geq k^{-m}\sum_{e\in\mathcal{E}}w_{e}\geq k^{-m}\cdot OPT.bold_E [ italic_W ] = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e âˆˆ caligraphic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_E [ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] â‰¥ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e âˆˆ caligraphic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_O italic_P italic_T .

(B2).Â  De-randomization via conditional expectation.Â  We first establish

Claim:Â  The RWAE2 problem is self-reducible [24, Chap. A.5].

In fact, assume Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a partial assignment from ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}caligraphic_V, such that variables X1,â‹¯,Xisubscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{1},\cdots,X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are mapped to {0,1}01\{0,1\}{ 0 , 1 }. Let â„°ssuperscriptâ„°ğ‘ {\cal E}^{s}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the set of equations satisfied by Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with total weight Wâ¢[Es]ğ‘Šdelimited-[]superscriptğ¸ğ‘ W[E^{s}]italic_W [ italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], and â„°usuperscriptâ„°ğ‘¢{\cal E}^{u}caligraphic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the set of equations which cannot be satisfied under Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let Eâ€²â€²superscriptğ¸â€²â€²E^{\prime\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a set of equations from â„°âˆ–(â„°sâˆªâ„°u)â„°superscriptâ„°ğ‘ superscriptâ„°ğ‘¢{\cal E}\smallsetminus({\cal E}^{s}\cup{\cal E}^{u})caligraphic_E âˆ– ( caligraphic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆª caligraphic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), such that variables from X1,â‹¯,Xisubscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{1},\cdots,X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are replaced by their values. By additivity of the weight function and the independence of the variables, the maximal weight of satisfied equations under an assignment which extends Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Wâ¢[Es]+mâ¢aâ¢xâ¢Wâ¢[Eâ€²â€²]ğ‘Šdelimited-[]superscriptğ¸ğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘Šdelimited-[]superscriptğ¸â€²â€²W[E^{s}]+maxW[E^{\prime\prime}]italic_W [ italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] + italic_m italic_a italic_x italic_W [ italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], where Wâ¢[Eâ€²â€²]ğ‘Šdelimited-[]superscriptğ¸â€²â€²W[E^{\prime\prime}]italic_W [ italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] is a solution of the RWAE2 problem restricted to Eâ€²â€²superscriptğ¸â€²â€²E^{\prime\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It is good enough to consider the self-reducibility trees Tğ‘‡Titalic_T such only one variable from each bag gets value 1111 along any path in the tree. This establishes our claim.

Assume that a self-reducibility tree Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is given, with each node in it corresponding to a step of the self-reduction. Each node vğ‘£vitalic_v of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is labelled with X1=a1,â‹¯,Xi=aiformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–X_{1}=a_{1},\cdots,X_{i}=a_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a partial assignment of values to variables X1,â‹¯,Xiâˆˆğ’±subscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ’±X_{1},\cdots,X_{i}\in\mathcal{V}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_V associated to the step for vğ‘£vitalic_v of the self-reduction. Since this is a partial assignment, some of the equations in â„°â„°\cal Ecaligraphic_E become immediately satisfied, other unsatisfied, and some other undetermined. The latter become a set of equations Eâ€²superscriptğ¸â€²E^{\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT associated to vğ‘£vitalic_v on variables ğ’±âˆ–{X1,â€¦,Xi}ğ’±subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–{\cal V}\smallsetminus\{X_{1},\ldots,X_{i}\}caligraphic_V âˆ– { italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, obtained from â„°â„°\cal Ecaligraphic_E by giving to the variables X1,â€¦,Xisubscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–X_{1},\ldots,X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT their values a1,â€¦,aisubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{1},\ldots,a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By construction, these equations inherit the weight of the corresponding equations in â„°â„°\cal Ecaligraphic_E.

For example, if the set of equations consists of: (1), yâ¢pâ¢(1âˆ’x)=1ğ‘¦ğ‘1ğ‘¥1yp(1-x)=1italic_y italic_p ( 1 - italic_x ) = 1, (2) 2â¢xâ¢zâ¢(1âˆ’y)=12ğ‘¥ğ‘§1ğ‘¦12xz(1-y)=12 italic_x italic_z ( 1 - italic_y ) = 1, (3) 3â¢xâ¢wâ¢(1âˆ’y)=13ğ‘¥ğ‘¤1ğ‘¦13xw(1-y)=13 italic_x italic_w ( 1 - italic_y ) = 1, with variables x,y,z,p,wğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘¤x,y,z,p,witalic_x , italic_y , italic_z , italic_p , italic_w, and the partial assignment, at some step of self-reduction for vğ‘£vitalic_v is x=1,y=0,w=1formulae-sequenceğ‘¥1formulae-sequenceğ‘¦0ğ‘¤1x=1,y=0,w=1italic_x = 1 , italic_y = 0 , italic_w = 1, then equation (1) becomes unsatisfiable, (2) is not satisfied but possibly satisfiable with an appropriate value for zğ‘§zitalic_z; and (3) satisfied. So, Eâ€²superscriptğ¸â€²E^{\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contains equation (2), but with x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,yitalic_x , italic_y replaced by their values 1,0101,01 , 0, resp.

The conditional expectation of any node vğ‘£vitalic_v in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T can be computed via its sets of equations Eâ€²superscriptğ¸â€²E^{\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we just described. Clearly, the expected weight of satisfied equations of Eâ€²superscriptğ¸â€²E^{\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT under a random assignment of values in ğºğ¹â¢[2]ğºğ¹delimited-[]2{\it GF}[2]italic_GF [ 2 ] to ğ’±âˆ–X1,â‹¯,Xiğ’±subscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–\mathcal{V}\setminus X_{1},\cdots,X_{i}caligraphic_V âˆ– italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be computed in the polynomial time. Adding to this the weight of the equations in â„°â„°\cal Ecaligraphic_E already satisfied by the partial assignment X1=a1,â‹¯,Xi=aiformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–X_{1}=a_{1},\cdots,X_{i}=a_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â‹¯ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT gives the conditional expectation.

Then we compute in polynomial time a path from the root to a leaf, such that the conditional expectation of each node on this path is â‰¥ğ„â¢[W]absentğ„delimited-[]ğ‘Š\geq\mathbf{E}[W]â‰¥ bold_E [ italic_W ]. This can be done as in the construction in [24, Theorem 16.4].

In consequence, we can find a deterministic approximate solution to the RWAE2 problem in polynomial time. It approximates the optimum solution with a factor greater then kâˆ’msuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šk^{-m}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It means that we can approximate the maximal value of aggregate conjunctive query within a factor kâˆ’msuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘šk^{-m}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which depends on integrity constraints and a query, but not depend on the size of the database. This ends the proof.

For example, the query with sum used in the proof of the NP-hardness in Theorem 6.2 has m=4,k=2formulae-sequenceğ‘š4ğ‘˜2m=4,k=2italic_m = 4 , italic_k = 2, then it can be approximated within the factor 2âˆ’4superscript242^{-4}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. â–¡â–¡\Boxâ–¡

0.A.2 An Example for Theorem 4.1

Consider the diophantine equation

2â¢x3â¢y2+3â¢xâ¢y+105=x2â¢y3+y2.2superscriptğ‘¥3superscriptğ‘¦23ğ‘¥ğ‘¦105superscriptğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘¦3superscriptğ‘¦22x^{3}y^{2}+3xy+105=x^{2}y^{3}+y^{2}.2 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 3 italic_x italic_y + 105 = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (5)

Each term tğ‘¡titalic_t in it will be represented by a relation Râ¢(t)ğ‘…ğ‘¡R(t)italic_R ( italic_t ) with 8 attributes taking values in â„•â„•\mathbb{N}blackboard_N: three, X1,X2,X3subscriptğ‘‹1subscriptğ‘‹2subscriptğ‘‹3X_{1},X_{2},X_{3}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for the maximum exponent of xğ‘¥xitalic_x, three, Y1,Y2,Y3subscriptğ‘Œ1subscriptğ‘Œ2subscriptğ‘Œ3Y_{1},Y_{2},Y_{3}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for the maximum exponent of yğ‘¦yitalic_y, one, Cğ¶Citalic_C, for the constant terms, plus a last one, Kğ¾Kitalic_K, for a key. Value 0 for a non-key attribute indicates that the term appears in tğ‘¡titalic_t, otherwise it gets value 1. We introduce as many tuples in Râ¢(t)ğ‘…ğ‘¡R(t)italic_R ( italic_t ) as the coefficient of the term; they differ only in the key value. We will see that only the 0 values will be subject to fixes. These are the relations and their ICs:

Now we construct a single table Râ¢(ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢)ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢R({\it equ})italic_R ( italic_equ ) that represents equation (5) by appending the previous tables:

Râ¢(ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢)ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢R({\it equ})italic_R ( italic_equ ) X1subscriptğ‘‹1X_{1}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT X2subscriptğ‘‹2X_{2}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT X3subscriptğ‘‹3X_{3}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Y1subscriptğ‘Œ1Y_{1}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Y2subscriptğ‘Œ2Y_{2}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Y3subscriptğ‘Œ3Y_{3}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Cğ¶Citalic_C Kğ¾Kitalic_K

We need ICs stating the correspondence between the terms in the tables Râ¢(t)ğ‘…ğ‘¡R(t)italic_R ( italic_t ) and table Râ¢(ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢)ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢R({\it equ})italic_R ( italic_equ ):

Finally, we have one aggregate constraint that is responsible for making equal the LHS and RHS of equation (5):

sumRâ¢(ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢)(x1â‹…x2â‹…x3â‹…x4â‹…x5â‹…x6â‹…x7:x6<7)=sumRâ¢(ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢)(x1â‹…x2â‹…x3â‹…x4â‹…x5â‹…x6â‹…x7:x6>6).sum_{R({\it equ})}(x_{1}\cdot x_{2}\cdot x_{3}\cdot x_{4}\cdot x_{5}\cdot x_{6}\cdot x_{7}~{}:x_{6}<7)~{}=~{}~{}~{}~{}sum_{R({\it equ})}(x_{1}\cdot x_{2}\cdot x_{3}\cdot x_{4}\cdot x_{5}\cdot x_{6}\cdot x_{7}~{}:x_{6}>6).italic_s italic_u italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R ( italic_equ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 7 ) = italic_s italic_u italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R ( italic_equ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 6 ) .

If the database has an LS-fix, then there is an integer solution to the diophantine equation. If the equation has a solution sğ‘ sitalic_s, then there is an instance Râ¢(eâ¢qâ¢u)â€²ğ‘…superscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢â€²R(equ)^{\prime}italic_R ( italic_e italic_q italic_u ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT corresponding to sğ‘ sitalic_s that satisfies the ICs. By Proposition 1, there is an LS-fix of the database.

The reduction could be done with the table Râ¢(ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢)ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¢R({\it equ})italic_R ( italic_equ ) alone, making all the ICs above to refer to this table, but the presentation would be harder to follow.
